filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of digital editions of Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copy U, from Princeton University Library, and Copy W, from King’s College, Cambridge University. Both are late copies and join Copies A, B, C, E, F, L, N, R, T, V, Y, Z, and AA, already available in the Archive.
Songs Copy U was printed in orange ink, given orange frame lines and page numbers, and finished in watercolors and pen and ink. It was produced in the same style on the same Ruse & Turner paper as Songs Copy T, The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G, The Book of Urizen Copy G, Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copies O, N, and P, The Book of Thel Copies N and O, and Milton Copy D. This set of illuminated books—which, with the exception of Visions Copy N, are in the Archive—was produced in 1818 and represents Blake’s return to illuminated printing. Except for a few copies of Songs and Milton between 1802 and 1811, Blake had not printed an illuminated book—or a group of them together—since 1795.
These late copies of illuminated books are often referred to as “elaborately colored,” but that fails to do them justice. The pages do not resemble lightly washed manuscripts or drawings, like the first copies (1789-93), or oil sketches, like color printed copies or books of designs (1794-96); nor do they resemble the hand-colored large paper copies of 1795. The pages are highly finished watercolor drawings. Blake printed the full plate (no wiping of borders) in bright reddish or orangish ink, finished the impressions in transparent and translucent washes and stippling brushwork, and carefully outlined texts and figures in pen and ink. The attention to detail was sustained throughout, and the designs often contain shell gold and were given a single thin red line or floral border to frame the image and thereby emphasize their autonomy as paintings in watercolor.
The renewal of Blake’s vigorous commitment to the illuminated books is evident in the ornate, beautifully colored impressions of Songs Copy W, printed in 1825 on large sheets of J Whatman 1825 paper (approximately 28 x 22 cm.) that give the small plates (approximately 11.5 x 7 cm.) wide margins that serve to frame the images. The untrimmed sheets for objects 1, 3, and 42 are shown as supplementary images. As in Songs Copy Y, its companion copy, each of the designs in Copy W is decoratively framed with vines, curtains, and other motifs drawn in green watercolor, probably by Catherine Blake, who described the copy as being “especially precious from having been ‘Blake’s own’” (Alexander Gilchrist, Life of William Blake [1863], 1:365). She sold it for £10.10 to John Jebb, Bishop of Limerick, in 1830. Like Copy U, the plates of Copy W are ordered 1 through 54, as they are in seven of the last eight copies printed (Copy V is the exception). Blake based this plate order—now considered standard for all print editions—with slight variations on Songs Copy R, printed in 1795 and his personal copy until he refinished it in 1819 for John Linnell, his new patron (see the 14 December 1999 Update for Songs Copy R).
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: William Blake Blake's name is given as the "printer" on the title pages to *Songs of Innocence* and *Songs of Experience*, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not recorded in the volume, but Blake lived in London during its printing.
imprint.date: 1789, 1794The 1789 imprint appears on the title page to *Songs of Innocence*, the 1794 imprint on the title page to *Songs of Experience*. There is no date on the general, combined title page.

objdescid.compdate: 1789, 1794Objects 2-28, 34-36, 53, and 54 as arranged in this copy (Bentley Plates 2-28, 34-36, 53, and 54) composed 1789; Objects 1, 29-33, 37-52 as arranged in this copy (Bentley Plates 1, 29-33, 37-52) composed 1794.

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.4 x 7.9 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching, with some white-line etching in the *Songs of Innocence* plates, and hand coloring in water colors with touches of shell gold and silver.
objinfo.watermark: RUSE & TURNERS / 1815The watermark appears on Objects 4, 11, 12, 18, 21, 26, 29, 31, 38, 41, 44, 47, and 48.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-54 upper right on Objects 1-54 in pen and orange or red ink
objinfo.framelines: 1The ink color of the framing lines matches the printing ink. There are also lines drawn at the edges of the images on most plates.
objinfo.binding: green moroccoThis binding was present by 1824, as recorded in the Rivingtons and Cochran catalogue of that year (see the Note on Provenance, below).

provenance.name: Princeton University Library
provenance.note: Probably acquired by James Boswell no later than Feb. 1822 (his death date); offered by Rivingtons and Cochran, 1824 catalogue, item 11,795 (£8.8s.); apparently the dealer Thomas Edwards, sold from his collection, Stewart, Wheatley, & Adlard auction, London, 15 May 1828, lot 940 (£2.13s. to "Clarke," probably a dealer); William Beckford, sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 4 July 1882, lot 951 (£146 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); offered by Quaritch in his *Rough List* 58, 30 July 1882, item 202 (£170), *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts*, Oct. 1883, item 10,250 (£170), sales pamphlet of *William Blake's Original Drawings*, May 1885 and Nov. 1886, page 2, no item number (£170), *General Catalogue of Books*, vol. 2, 1887, item 10,250 (£170), *A Catalogue of Works of Bibliography and Literary History* 104, May 1890, item 459 (£170), *Miscellaneous Catalogue of Rare Old Books* no. 61 of 1891, a note on page 12 stating that this copy "can be had from me for £170," *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts* 109, Feb. 1891, item 92 (£170), *Miscellaneous Catalogue of Rare Old Books* no. 62 of 1893, page 30, no item number (£170), *Miscellaneous Catalogue of Valuable, Rare, and Curious Books*, Nov. 1893, page 4, no item number (£170), and *Rough List* 147, Jan. 1895, page 46, no item number (£170); acquired by William A. White in Oct. 1895; given by White to his daughter, Mrs. Hugh D. Marshall, no later than 1927; sold by Mrs. Marshall to her brother, Harold T. White, after 1939, or possibly sold to Emily de F. White who in turn gave the book to Harold T. White in 1947 (see Bentley page 422); Caroline Newton after 1947; given by Newton to Princeton University Library in March 1967.

desc.objtitle:
General Title Page Songs of Innocence and of Experience,
Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude figures—the only vestiges of clothing are vines or branches with a scattering of leaves around their loins—bend severely to the left, their bodies curved away from a powerful burst of flames and smoke(?) that extends all the way across the plate from the right margin. They seem to represent Adam and Eve being driven from the paradise in Eden. Eve, the long-haired lower figure, bends almost to a prone position, as if she has been crawling on the ground. Her head is turned toward the viewer. Her right leg is drawn up under her and her left is extended behind. Her visible arm is extended beyond her head on the ground. Adam's body is bent over hers. His legs are spread and he clasps his head in his arms. The two bent bodies and the flames form concentric arches. Although the flames rise to the top right corner of the plate, the text of the title and subtitle begins in the area of sky that is visible at upper left; the title descends line by line into their midst, ending just over Adam and Eve's arched bodies. An ascending bird spreads its wings in the area to the right of the first "Of" (line 3). The initial "S," the "N," and the final "S" of "SONGS" (line 2) have extravagant vine-like extensions. Dark wash that may represent shadow stretches across the bottom of the plate; it is widest at the bottom left corner and grows narrower as it extends toward the bottom right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: Two nude figures—the only vestiges of clothing are vines or branches with a scattering of leaves around their loins—bend severely to the left, their bodies curved away from a powerful burst of flames that extends all the way across the plate from the right margin. They seem to represent Adam and Eve being driven from the paradise in Eden. Eve, the long-haired lower figure, bends almost to a prone position, as if she has been crawling on the ground. Her head is twisted toward the viewer and her mouth is open. Her right leg is drawn up under her and her left is extended behind. Her visible arm is extended beyond her head on the ground.

Two nude figures—the only vestiges of clothing are vines or branches with a scattering of leaves around their loins—bend severely to the left, their bodies curved away from a powerful burst of flames that extends all the way across the plate from the right margin. They seem to represent Adam and Eve being driven from the paradise in Eden. Adam's body is bent over Eve's. His legs are spread and his visible hand clutches his lowered head. His hair would appear to be short and curly.

Two mostly nude figures, apparently Adam and Eve, bend severely to the left, their bodies curved away from a powerful burst of flames that extends all the way across the plate from the right margin. The flames and smoke(?) extend to the top right corner of the plate but give way to flame-like vegetation in the top left quadrant. Some of the letters of the title have flame-like extensions.

The ground beneath the figures bears slight indications of grass. Beneath the grass, dark wash that may represent shadow stretches across the bottom of the plate; it is widest at the bottom left corner and grows narrower as it extends toward the bottom right corner.
An ascending bird spreads its wings in the area to the right of the first "Of" (line 3).

Two tiny human figures—one sitting and bending forward in a contracted position (probably facing right), the other standing and probably facing right—occupy the lower curve of the initial "S" (line 2). The standing figure may have one arm (the right?) raised vertically.
The initial "S" (line 2) is extended at the top into a bifurcated upward-sprouting bit of flame- like vegetation and at the bottom into a vine-like furl with one loop.
The "N" of "SONGS" (line 2) is extended downward to suggest flame-like vegetation.
The lower curve of the terminal "S" of "SONGS" (line 2) is extended to suggest a vine or flame that reaches toward a flame-like outline rising up the right margin.
Several letters of the title and subtitle beginning with the "C" of "INNOCENCE" (line 4) have flame-like vegetative extensions that integrate them with the surrounding fire.
A blue sky is visible above the flames and smoke(?).

lg.l: SONGS
Of
INNOCENCE
and Of
EXPERIENCE
Shewing the Two Contrary States
of the Human Soul.

desc.objtitle:
Frontispiece to Songs of Innocence,
Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired partly nude male (in green, semi-transparent tights), holding a musical pipe, walks toward the viewer with his left leg forward. This shepherd-piper looks up to the right at a cherubic nude male(?) infant or child floating in a horizontal position above his head in an area of sky or cloud. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. The plate is framed by trees on both sides whose leafy branches arch across the top. Behind the piper are grazing sheep and, in the background, more trees.

component.illusobjdesc: A partly nude male (in green, semi-transparent tights) with long and curly hair, holding a musical pipe, strides toward the viewer with his left leg forward. Both arms are bent at the elbow. The body of this shepherd-piper faces forward but he looks up to the right at a cherubic male(?) child.

A cherubic nude male(?) infant or child with short, curly hair hovers in a horizontal position above the head of a shepherd-piper in an area of sky or cloud. The child, with his arms raised horizontally, his hands raised with palms facing up and out, and his legs spread, looks down at the piper.
A cherubic male(?) child flies in an area of sky or cloud above the shepherd-piper's head.
A flock of sheep grazes behind the shepherd-piper. Two in the front have their heads down.

Trees frame the plate on both sides. The tree on the left has a single trunk, while the two trees on the right intertwine. Their leafy branches form an arch overhead. There are more leafy trees in the background.
The ground beneath the shepherd-piper would appear to be covered with grass.
Shadows extend left of the shepherd-piper's feet.
A male shepherd holds a musical pipe.

desc.objtitle:
Title Page for Songs of Innocence,
Object 3 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a boy with short, curly hair; the gowned child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. To the right of the group is a large apple(?) tree bearing fruit; around the trunk loosely spirals a vine. The upper leaves of the tree are integrated with the letters of "SONGS" (line 2). There may be the suggestion of a second tree on the horizon in the background just to the right of the tree in the foreground. Various small figures can be seen among the letters of the title. Birds fly in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" and above the "N" in "SONGS." Another bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence" (line 4). The band of color at the bottom of the plate suggests a river. Coloring in the lower portions of the sky suggest a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds a book that two children read.
In her lap a nurse or mother holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a male with short, curly hair; he wears at least a shirt, perhaps a gown.

In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read, standing. The gowned child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with the forearm raised horizontally. Her left hand may be pointing to a passage in the book.
In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read or at least look at.
A nurse or mother sits in a chair that faces right.

To the right of the nurse or mother and two children is a large apple(?) tree, bearing fruit (around "of" in the title [line 3]); around its trunk loosely spirals a vine. The flame-like upper leaves of the tree are integrated with the letters of "SONGS" (leafy extensions of the initial "S," the "N," and the terminal "S" are particularly extravagant [line 2]). There may be the suggestion of a second tree on the horizon in the background, just to the right of the tree in the foreground.
There are slight suggestions of a vine or tree trunk along the right margin of the plate, right of the large tree.
There is a small hill or mound in the distant landscape on the horizon, just left of the tree.
There may be a figure, facing left, sitting on the mid-stroke of the initial "S" in "SONGS." The figure's left(?) leg dangles below the letter.
In the "O" of "SONGS" (line 2) is a kneeling figure with arms raised horizontally. We probably see this figure from behind.
A standing, winged figure leans against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2). The figure may be looking down at and holding a book, reading or writing.
The figure leaning against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2) may be holding a book.
There may be a figure standing on the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2) with arms raised horizontally or bent at the elbow.
A gowned(?) female(?) figure with both arms raised vertically stands in the "G" of "SONGS" (line 2). Her body faces to the left.
There may be a tiny seated figure, hunched over and facing right, in the lower curve of the final "S" of "SONGS" (line 2).
A male piper(?) with a broad-brimmed hat, perhaps holding a pipe, stands facing left and leaning against the "I" of "Innocence" (line 4).
A bird flies upward in the sky beneath and to the left of the initial "S" in "SONGS" (line 2).
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2).
A bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence" (line 4).

The coloring of the horizontal band at the lower edge of the plate suggests a river (cf. the following object, "Introduction" [object 4]). There are slight suggestions of two rivers (or some bodies of water) in the middle distance of the landscape.
The coloring of the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: SONGS
of
Innocence
The Author & Printer WBlake

desc.objtitle:
Introduction,
Object 4 (Bentley 4, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two indistinct, possibly gowned figures, the front one seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude(?) figure; (3) a standing figure, facing right with arms down and bent slightly at the waist; (4) a figure seen from the waist up, looking down at what appears to be a cradle; (5) at top right, a bird flying against a background of indeterminate vegetation(?); (6) a seated figure with a prominent left knee and perhaps with arms resting in the figure's lap; (7) a solitary standing figure with what might be two flying birds to the right and a third above; (8) a seated figure, probably gowned, facing to the right and with head bent slightly downward. To the left of this figure left is a narrow object that may be a staff or shepherd's crook held by the figure. A bird may fly above this figure’s head. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas. A river flows across the bottom of the plate. The background of the text is washed to suggest an area of sky and cloud; the rosy and yellow color of this wash suggests a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins leafy vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils, some of them (top, bottom) loopy, that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.
A river flows across the bottom of the plate.
In the panel at top left there are two indistinct, gowned figures. The one in the foreground is seated and facing right. The background figure, on the right, may be standing or sitting.
In the second panel down from top left, a nude figure runs or leaps toward us with legs spread and arms raised to 135 degrees.
In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure, facing right, with arms down and bending over slightly at the waist.
In the bottom panel on the left is a shape that may be a cradle. Behind is the upper body of a figure, perhaps looking at a child (not pictured) in the cradle.
In the bottom panel on the left is a shape that may be a cradle. Behind is the upper body of a figure, perhaps looking at a child (not pictured) in the cradle.

In the panel at top right is a bird flying against a background of indeterminate vegetation(?). There may be three more birds in the third panel from the top on this side, and one more in the bottom panel.
In the second panel from top right is a seated figure with a prominent left knee and perhaps with arms resting on the figure's lap.
In the third panel from top right is a solitary standing figure, possibly with two birds flying to the right and a third above.

In the bottom panel on the lower right is a seated figure, probably gowned, facing forward and with head bent slightly downward. To this figure’s left is a narrow object that may be a staff or shepherd's crook held by the figure's raised right hand. A bird may fly above this figure’s head.

The background tinting in the text area and within the panels created by the vines suggests sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. This coloring helps to integrate the text area with the vines, which seem to be rooted in ground at the bottom of the plate, into one design.

lg.l: Piping down the valleys wild
Piping songs of pleasant glee
On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me,
Pipe a song about a Lamb;
So I piped with merry chear,
Piper pipe that song again__
So I piped, he wept to hear,
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear.
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle:
The Shepherd,
Object 5 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks forward, and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hilltop in the background, where the sky suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the light. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird, while two others perch on the branch just below.

component.illusobjdesc: A young male shepherd with short, curly hair wears tights and stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep—perhaps looking at the sheep that lifts its head toward him. He holds a crook in his left hand; his purse is visible near his right knee. His arms are bent at the elbow, with his body facing forward but his head turned to the left.

A shepherd watches his grazing flock of sheep. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. The rest of the grazing sheep appear to have their heads lowered to the ground, including several in the front and the one that may be a ram.

Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees in the background.
Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom.
The coloring on the ground beneath the sheep suggests grass.
There are trees and a hilltop in the background, where the color of the sky, purple on the far left and rosy elsewhere, suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset.
The color of the sky, purple on the far left and rosy elsewhere, suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset.
On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the sky. Three much smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird, and two others perch on the branch just below.
The shepherd's purse is visible beside his right knee.
The shepherd holds a crook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves or flowers branches off the "T" in "The" in the title (line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves or flowers branches off the "T" in "The" in the title (line 2).

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot,
From the morn to the evening he strays;
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call.
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace,
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green The Echoing Green,
Object 6 (Bentley 6, Erdman 6, Keynes 6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of four adults (the text mentions "old folk" and "mothers" on object 6, line 16 and object 7, line 12, respectively), including two long-haired(?) males wearing brimmed hats and two females—one wearing a scarf over her head (center), the other a cap (right)—sit presumably on a circular bench at the base of the trunk of a large oak tree. They superintend four young children who stand at their knees. Behind them five older children play and stroll on a grassy area. The dense, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other, much smaller, trees or bushes line the background. Rosy wash behind this background vegetation suggests a sunrise or sunset, and portions of dark blue sky are visible at the top left and top right corners. The tree casts a shadow on the lower right of the design, which may suggest "the darkening Green" of line 17 on the following object.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adult males in brimmed hats. The adult furthest left may be looking down at the small child at his knee, who is looking up at him. He may have long hair and may be among the "old folk" (line 17). The man appears to be gowned. His left arm is at his side and rests in his lap.

On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adult males in brimmed hats. The second adult from the left, hands on his knees, left leg forward, seems to be looking toward the children playing to the left behind the tree. He may be wearing breeches and a coat. Long-haired, he may be among the "old folk" (line 17).
A small child with short hair(?) stands at the knees of the first adult male sitting on the left side of the tree trunk and looks up at him.

Two females in full gowns and headdress—nurses or the "mothers" (object 7, line 12) mentioned in the text— sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. There are two children standing in front of the woman in the center, one at each knee. She faces forward, but looks down toward the child on the right. Her right arm rests on the back of and perhaps holds the child at left. She wears a scarf over her head.
Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the left, in a gown, lays its head in her lap, face toward the viewer, and may be sleeping.

Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the right, short-haired, clothed in green tights and probably male, reaches up with his right hand and rests his left on her knee. He may be holding the woman's left arm with his right hand. He is facing away from the viewer.

Two females in full gowns and headdress—nurses or the "mothers" (object 7, line 12) mentioned in the text— sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. A child stands at the knees of the woman on the right, and she holds an infant in her lap while cradling it with her arms. She looks down at the children.
A child stands at the knees of a woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree. The child on the right looks away to the right; his(?) mouth may be slightly open.
The woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree holds an infant or very young child in her lap.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children in tights play an unidentified ball game. The child at far left, who faces away from the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his right arm at his side, and holding a bat with his raised left hand. His hair is short and may be curly.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children in tights play an unidentified ball game. The short-haired child second from left, who faces forward, stands with his legs spread, his arms raised horizontally, and his palms either up or facing the viewer.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children—the nearest one dressed as a male—walk together, facing left. The front-most youth holds his bent left arm at his side.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children walk together, facing left. The child back and furthest right looks to the left, his head slightly turned up.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. To the right of the tree trunk stands a short-haired(?) child, arms at his(?) side, who may be playing a ball game with the two standing children to the left of the trunk.
The thick-leaved, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree, perhaps an oak, spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other, much smaller, trees or bushes line the background.
The child at the far left holds a bat in his upraised left hand, and there is a ball in the air just to the left of his head.
Rosy wash behind the trees in the background suggests a sunrise or sunset, and portions of dark blue sky are visible at the top left and top right corners.
A shadow extends to the right from the figures seated around the tree.
A large grassy area—possibly the "darkening Green" of line 17 on the following object— spreads beneath and behind the central oak tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, dressed in a shirt and long breeches, stands erect, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. The one on the right, dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand. Leafy grapevines flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a loopy tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza. These grapevines appear to be rooted in a narrow stretch of earth that extends across the text area’s bottom margin. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. Some tendrils sprout from the initial "T," and the final "n" (line 2) is just above a vine with buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath. A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes. Light blue wash behind the boy on the left suggests sky; streaks of rosy wash on the right side of the text area suggest a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and long breeches, stands erect in contrapposto, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right.
Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the right, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand.

Leafy grapevines flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a loopy tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza. These grapevines appear to be rooted in a narrow stretch of earth that extends across the text area’s bottom margin. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. Some tendrils sprout from the initial "T," and the final "n" (line 2) is just above a vine with buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath.
The boy on the left holds a bat by his side.
The boy on the right runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand.
A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes.
Light blue wash behind the boy on the left suggests sky; streaks of rosy wash on the right side of the text area suggest a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: The Sun does arise
And make happy the skies.
The merry bells ring
To welcome the Spring.
The sky-lark and thrush,
The birds of the bush,
Sing louder around,
To the bells chearful sound.
While our sports shall be seen
On the Ecchoing Green.
Old John with white hair
Does laugh away care,
Sitting under the oak,
Among the old folk,

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green (continued) The Echoing Green (continued),
Object 7 (Bentley 7, Erdman 7, Keynes 7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a background hinting, by the darkness on the lower right, at twilight on the "darkening Green" (line 17), a procession of nine adults and children (including one infant) in a variety of positions moves generally leftward. Overhead in the branches of two luxuriant, intertwining grape vines that are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin and left to embrace the stanzas of the poem, one boy, left, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes on the left while a second boy, right, hands another cluster to a girl who reaches up from the grass below. Next to her, walking left, is a long-haired male in hat and tights or breeches; with his left hand he holds out a cluster of grapes toward a small boy in front of him while, between them, a woman looks down at the infant in her arms. In the center, the tallest figure in the group, perhaps "Old John with white hair," (object 6, line 13) points forward with his right hand and with his other hand reaches down toward the boy to the left. That boy, who faces away from the viewer, holds a bat at his side with his left hand. At the front of the procession are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that the girl may be holding. A strip of dark blue streaked with grey, perhaps a river, extends across the bottom margin of the illustration.

component.illusobjdesc: Standing on a branch of a luxuriant grapevine, a short-haired boy with his head bent back, seen in profile, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes with his upraised right arm. He wears tights.

Lying on a branch of a luxuriant grape vine, a boy in tights hands a cluster of grapes down to a girl on the grass below. His right leg is bent at the knee and he seems to look forward or to the left rather than down toward the girl. His hair is short and may be curly; his left arm wraps around the grapevine.

A girl in a full gown and a brown hat with a yellow rim that resembles a halo reaches up with her left hand to take a cluster of grapes from a boy lying on the grapevine above her. She looks up toward the grapes.

Walking left among the lower group of figures, second from right, is a long-haired youthful male in brimmed hat and tights; with his left hand he holds out a cluster of grapes toward a small boy in front of him.

Among the lower group of figures, third from the right, stands (or walks) a woman in a full gown who looks down at the infant in her arms. She faces left. Her hair seems to be pulled back in a bun, possibly with a scarf over it.
Among the lower group of figures, fourth from the right and crowded between two larger adults, stands or walks a small boy in tights who looks forward and left.
There is an infant in the arms of the woman third from the right among the lower group of figures.

In the center of the lower group of figures, the tallest figure, with long hair, brimmed hat, and dressed in coat and breeches or tights—perhaps "Old John with white hair" (object 6, line 13)—points forward with his right hand and with his other hand reaches down toward the boy to the left.

Among the lower group of figures, third from the left, facing away from the viewer, stands (in a contrapposto posture) or walks a curly-haired boy in breeches or tights who holds a bat at his side with his left hand.

At the front of the procession of figures are a boy, with short hair and dressed in tights or breeches, and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. The boy's arms are at his side; his head and shoulders are silhouetted against the kite behind him.
At the front of the procession of figures are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that she may be holding. She is long-haired and wears a gown.

A luxuriant grapevine, or rather two vines intertwined, are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin. One vine continues up the right margin, while the other branches left to embrace the stanzas of the poem. There are leaves here and there on the vines, a grape cluster at the upper left, over the head of a boy who stretches to pick it, another cluster in the lowered hand of the boy in the vine on the right, and a third cluster in the extended left hand of the boy walking to the left, second figure from the right. A strip of grass extends from the left to right margin.
There are two children's toys in the lower procession of figures: a kite between the boy and girl on the left, and a bat held by the boy to the right of them.

The blue and golden sky behind the lower procession of figures, and especially the darkness on the lower right, is colored to give the suggestion of sunset—the "darkening Green" (line 17) of the text. Cloud bands extend across the sky above the procession of figures. Blue wash behind the boy in the branches on the left suggests more sky, and rosy and golden wash behind the boy in the branches on the right further suggests sunset.
Behind the procession of figures, on the lower right of the plate, the gray area may be a cloud or shadow representing sunset—the "darkening Green" (line 17) of the text.
Shadows extend along the ground below the vine (lower right) and left of the feet of several figures.
A strip of dark blue streaked with grey, perhaps a river, extends across the bottom margin of the illustration.

lg.l: They laugh at our play,
And soon they all say,
Such such were the joys,
When we all girls & boys,
In our youth-time were seen,
On the Ecchoing Green.
Till the little ones weary
No more can be merry
The sun does descend,
And our sports have an end;
Round the laps of their mothers,
Many sisters and brothers,
Like birds in their nest,
Are ready for rest;
And sport no more seen,
On the darkening Green.

desc.objtitle:
The Lamb,
Object 8 (Bentley 8, Erdman 8, Keynes 8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short, curly hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands. Behind the flock are a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left) and a cottage or barn (right) with an open doorway. On its thatched(?) roof perch two birds, often identified as doves. Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas. A river runs across the bottom of the plate. The sky is lightly colored to extend across the entire upper area of the plate, integrating the text into the design. A dark blue area at the top left, and an especially dark area directly above the cottage on the right, may be dark clouds or darkening sky, suggesting sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short, curly hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep. He reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands. His head is bent slightly downward as he looks at the sheep.

In a grassy landscape, a nude boy stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands. The lamb appears to look up a the child.
Behind the flock of sheep is a leafy oak tree with a large trunk.

Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.
On the roof of a cottage or barn perch two birds, often identified as doves.
Behind the flock of sheep is a cottage or barn (right) with a thatched(?) roof and a doorway or window.
A dark shadow cuts diagonally across the top left corner of the door or window of the building.
In a grassy landscape, a nude boy stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep.

The sky is colored to extend across the entire upper area of the plate, integrating the text into the design. The coloring suggests sunrise or sunset. A dark blue area at the top left, and an especially dark area directly above the cottage on the right, may be dark clouds or darkening sky, further suggesting sunset.
A river runs across the bottom of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee clothing of delight,
Softest clothing wooly bright;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Making all the vales rejoice;
Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Little Lamb I'll tell thee,
Little Lamb I'll tell thee;
He is called by thy name,
For he calls himself a Lamb:
He is meek & he is mild,
He became a little child:
I a child & thou a lamb,
We are called by his name.
Little Lamb God bless thee,
Little Lamb God bless thee.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy,
Object 9 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) and "Little Black Boy" (title [line 2]) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A twining vine wraps twice around the tree trunk, its top loop protruding as a half-circle on the trunk’s right side. A second, smaller tree grows up the right margin and arches over the sun—a pattern echoed on the next object. The hilly plain that stretches to the treeless horizon seems to be covered with grass. A distant mountain may be visible on the right. "The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon. The sun's beams show distinctly against the clouds and contrast with the dark landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: Under a tree, a long-haired, dark-skinned adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. She points with her right index finger. Presumably she corresponds to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) of the text.

Under a tree, an adult female sits facing a kneeling(?) child, apparently nude, who points upward with his left hand and one raised finger. Presumably he is the "Little Black Boy" of the text (line 2). They are both dark of skin. The child seems to be looking up at the female.
The mother and child sit under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother.
A twining vine wraps twice around the tree trunk on the illustration’s left, its top loop protruding as a half-circle on the trunk’s right side.
"The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts in the sky above the horizon.
A second tree, much smaller than the one on the left, grows up the right margin and arches over the rising sun—a pattern echoed on the next object.
The hilly plain that stretches to the treeless horizon seems to be covered with grass.
The grassy, hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. A distant mountain may be visible on the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower panel suggests hills at the bottom with sky above. A pair of intertwined vines extends up the left margin and around the words of the title. From their termination on the lower left, a single vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above ground level, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below line 13. Another vine, or possibly a continuation of the lower vine, with loops and leaves fills the right margin above. The capital letters of the title are ornamented and colored to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black" (line 2). A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree."

component.illusobjdesc: A pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From their termination on the lower left, a single vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above ground level, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below the end of line 13. One extension of this vine descends in a spiral in the plate's lower right corner. Above, another vine with loops and leaves fills the remaining spaces right of the text. The capital letters of the title are ornamented with vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black" (line 2).
A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree."
There are low hills across the bottom of the plate.
The area behind and around the text is washed to suggest sky; its coloring, light blue on the far left with rosy streaks in the middle and at the right, suggests sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me.
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun! there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space..
That we may learn to bear the beams of love,
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy (continued),
Object 10 (Bentley 10, Erdman 10, Keynes 10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous object. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd, with beard, gown, halo (that doubles as the sun, echoing the previous object), and crook, sits facing left on a grassy bank. Two nude boys—the left dark-skinned, the right light-skinned in this copy—stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous object, stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Its roots are partially exposed on the grassy bank to the right. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy, and a river runs at the foot of the plate. The left and top margins of the plate are colored to suggest that the sky continues above the lower design to the top. A vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar vegetation extends from the tree to complete the circuit around the top and left side of the text. Another vine with intertwined branches rooted in the riverbank in the plate’s bottom left corner grows about a quarter of the way up the left margin; it may bear leaves or flowers. The willow-like tree is backed by leafy plants or trees.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, in conventional representation as shepherd, with long hair, beard, gown, halo (that doubles as the sun, echoing the previous object), and crook, sits facing left on a grassy bank with two children standing in front of him. He looks down at the child at his knees. Holding his crook between his legs and across his shoulder, he rests his left arm on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left foot is exposed.

To the left of the English boy and Christ, a second nude child with short, curly hair and dark skin, probably the little black boy from the previous object, stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12). The little black boy's legs may be crossed at the ankles.

The nude and long-haired "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem stands at Christ's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Christ, who looks down at him. The boy's right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy.
All three of the figures are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Its roots are partially exposed on the grassy bank to the right.
The willow-like tree is backed by leafy plants or trees.
A double vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. It has several flowers and/or leaves blooming on its stems.
A vine with intertwined branches rooted in the riverbank in the plate’s bottom left corner grows about a quarter of the way up the left margin; it may bear leaves or flowers.
Jesus sits on a grassy bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted. The grass covers the remainder of the landscape as well, down to the river in the foreground.
Jesus sits on a grassy bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted.
A river runs across the foot of the plate.
A shadow falls on the ground below the two children.
The left and top margins of the plate are colored to suggest that the sky continues above the lower design to the top edge of the plate.

The elements of the design echo a selection of those on the previous object. Christ's halo doubles as the sun (echoing the previous object). The coloring of the area behind the tree and most of the text suggests the sky of the previous object as well.
In a sitting position, Christ holds a shepherd's crook between his legs and across his shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flowering vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar vegetation extends from the tree and completes the circuit around the top and left side of the text. The vine at the top is flame-like and in the left margin is intertwined with another vine. A separate sprig of vegetation, possibly including one or two flowers, appears to the right of line 6.

component.illusobjdesc: A flowering and/or leaf-bearing vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar vegetation extends from the tree and completes the circuit around the top and left side of the text. The vine at the top is flame-like and in the left margin is intertwined with another vine. A separate sprig of vegetation, possibly including one or two flowers, appears to the right of line 6.
The left and top margins of the plate are colored to suggest that the sky continues above the lower design to the top. Washes in the text area hint at sky as well.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care.
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me.
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair:
And be like him and he will then love me.

desc.objtitle:
The Blossom,
Object 11 (Bentley 11, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, the extravagant flame-like structure of a flower without stem or leaves—perhaps the "happy Blossom" (lines 5, 11) of the text, although there it is personified—surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, with the suggestion of a halo to the right of her head, sitting on part of the blossom just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title; (3) she holds an infant in her arms (ill-defined and so barely visible in this copy but clearer in others); (4) to her left, a winged figure, nude(?), kneeling or sitting, facing left, and possibly reading or writing in a book or on a tablet; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from and the other facing toward the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. The blue background suggests the sky, with a darker area of blue wash behind and above the figures indicating that the time is just before dawn or just after dusk, and there is a narrow strip of grass at bottom.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures: at far right is a forward-facing nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically, its left foot forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures: in the center, a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, with the suggestion of a halo to the right of her head, sits on part of the blossom just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2). She holds an infant in her arms (ill-defined and so barely visible in this copy but clearer in others). Her extended right foot is prominent. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, this pair may be the female blossom who, as a mother-figure, addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. The adult female's wings thus resemble a part of the blossom.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures: in the center, a winged female(?) sitting on the blossom just above the "som" of "Blossom" (line 2) holds an infant in her arms (ill-defined and so barely visible in this copy but clearer in others). The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure, addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

The figures in the blossom probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure, addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures. Above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2) is a winged figure, nude(?), kneeling or sitting, facing left. This figure may be reading or writing in a tablet or book resting just to the left of the figure.
A book or tablet rests just to the left of the winged figure above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2).

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces away from the viewer is perhaps male(?). His arms are raised horizontally, and his legs are spread.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces forward is probably another nude putto, but might be female. Its arms are raised at 45 degrees, both to the right, and its legs are together, left forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of seven and perhaps eight figures. At top center is a second pair of winged nude figures facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). At least one leg of the figure on the left is extended backward. This figure is either sitting or kneeling; the figure on the right is more clearly kneeling.

Originating at lower right, the extravagant flame-like structure of a flower without stem or leaves—perhaps the "happy Blossom" (lines 5, 11) of the text, although there it is personified—surrounds the poem on three sides.
There is a narrow strip of grass at bottom.
The blue background suggests the sky, and a darker area of blue wash behind and above the figures indicates that the time is just before dawn or just after dusk.

lg.l: Merry Merry Sparrow
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Sees you swift as arrow
Seek your cradle narrow
Near my Bosom.
Pretty Pretty Robin
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Hears you sobbing sobbing
Pretty Pretty Robin
Near my Bosom.The period at the end of this line printed very lightly in this copy and is difficult to see.

desc.objtitle:
The Chimney Sweeper,
Object 12 (Bentley 12, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration seems to depict chimney sweeper Tom Dacre's dream of liberation for himself and his fellow sweeps by an angel, who releases them from their "coffins of black" to run "naked" down a "green plain" and "wash in a river" (lines 14-18). Below a background of sky are several small figures and leafy plants or a hedge. At bottom right a gowned adult bends forward, reaching toward a tiny nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text. Across the rest of the bottom of the plate are nude figures standing or running with their arms raised in various positions. Two pairs are embracing. The uncolored area at lower left suggests the river that the liberated boys wash themselves in. Behind the gowned adult a tree that grows up the right margin helps to tie the elements of the plate into a single design, as does the sky behind the text.

component.illusobjdesc: At bottom right a gowned adult, presumably the liberating angel of the text, bends forward, reaching toward, and holding the hand of, a child. There is a slight suggestion of a halo around the angel's head.
At bottom right a gowned adult reaches down toward a tiny nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the "coffins" (line 14) of the text.

A pair of figures (the ninth and tenth figures from the left) stands with their arms raised at 135 degrees; they may be holding hands. They are most likely two of the liberated nude boys of Tom Dacre's dream in the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
The seventh and eighth standing figures from the left embrace. These are presumably two of the naked liberated chimney sweepers of the text.

The fifth and sixth figures from the left in the group bottom left run with their arms raised. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
The third and fourth figures from the left in the group bottom left face each other and embrace. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text.

The first and second figures from the left in the group bottom left run to the left with their arms raised at 135 degrees. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
A thin, leafy, serpentine tree grows up the right margin. About halfway up it seems to give way to other vegetation.
Greenish areas amidst the group of liberated boys on the left suggest the "green plain" of the text (line 17).
Leafy plants or a hedge back the standing and running figures below the text.
The small figure second from the right appears to be rising out of the earth—perhaps one of the "coffins" (line 14) of the text.
The uncolored area at lower left suggests the river that the liberated boys wash themselves in.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against background washes that suggest the sky and clouds, the text and margins are busy with vegetative forms and at least five tiny human figures: a chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot and walking to the right within the "C" of the title, two or three figures sitting on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title, and a pair of figures sitting on the vine or tree right of lines 14-15. The interlinear decorations are linked to the major design at bottom by the tree rooted at lower right, which grows up the right margin until it breaks off about halfway up and is replaced by other, more fanciful forms of vegetation. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title (line 2) is a tiny figure that may be a right-facing chimney sweeper carrying a bag.
In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title (line 2) is a right-facing figure who may be a chimney sweeper carrying a bag.
Above the second "e" of "Sweeper" in the title (line 2) is a figure facing and leaning toward the left.

Above the first "e" of "Sweeper" in the title (line 2) is a figure facing toward the left. Its right arm is extended horizontally and may grasp the vegetation for support; its left arm is raised above it and may hold an indeterminate object. The vegetation left of this figure, to which he reaches or which he holds, might be another (but poorly-defined) figure.

A pair of figures face each other in the vine, or branches of a tree, right of lines 14-15. The figure on the left stands or leans against the vegetation at his or her back; his or her companion sits. Both have arms raised.

The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms. What in some other copies are tiny human figures are largely blended into the vegetation here. The interlinear decorations are linked to the major design at bottom by the tree rooted at lower right, which grows up the right margin until it breaks off about halfway up and is replaced by other, more fanciful forms of vegetation. The capital letters of the title (line 2) and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.
Background washes suggest the sky and clouds behind the text.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young,
And my father sold me while yet my tongue,
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head.
That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd, so I said,
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare,
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair.
And so he was quiet. & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick. Joe Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,Only fragments of the “c” in “black” printed in this copy.
And by came an Angel who had a bright key.
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.
run
Then down a green plain leaping laughing theyBlake apparently began to etch the word "run" at the end of line 18. Lacking sufficient space for the word, he etched it above line 18 (line 17).
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind,
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy.
He'd have God for his father & never want joy.
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm,
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy lost,
Object 13 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On hilly ground in the darkness, a small boy in a gown and wearing a hat holds his arms out toward a large area of bright light at the left. A leafless tree arches ominously over him from behind. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5). In the background, tall, green reeds arch to the left like the tree. Above these reeds, dark blue wash extends across the top margin, suggesting a night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: On hilly ground in the darkness, a small boy in a gown and wearing a hat holds his arms out toward a large area of bright light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2). His hair appears to be curly, and he may wear shoes.
A tree trunk and three or four of its branches arch ominously over the boy from behind. Though the text mentions "mire" (line 9), the area at his feet looks more like grass.
The boy wanders on hilly ground in the darkness.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a large area of bright light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10; i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5). The bright area exudes spiky beams of light that become dark radiance, nearly merging with the tall reeds in the background.
In the background, tall, green reeds arch to the left like the tree.
Above the tall reeds and the tree, dark blue wash extends across the top margin, suggesting a night sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The colors behind the text suggest the blue sky of day, though the poem refers to "The night" (line 7). The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, four of whom are winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are four flying birds and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza. Two human figures sit on the initial "L" of "Little" and the "B" of "Boy" in the title (line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: The colors behind the text suggest the blue sky of day, though the poem refers to "The night" (line 7).

A tiny human figure sits, facing left, on the upper stroke in the initial "L" of "Little" in the title (line 2). At least one arm is raised horizontally and at least one leg dangles downward. The figure may be holding an unidentifiable object in its hand. A line extending from this object to the figure's face suggests that this may be a musical pipe played by the figure.
A tiny human figure sits, facing left, at the bottom of the "B" of "Boy" in the title (line 2). One arm is raised at 135 degrees; one leg may be bent at the knee.

The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all probably female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They all seem to be gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with their arms, or at least one arm, raised (with banners or flags of drapery where the left arm of the left figure and the right arm of the right figure might otherwise be); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side has its left arm raised vertically.

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title (line 2), over "where" and "going" in line 3, and after "fast" in line 4. There is a swan or duck, facing right, above the "y" of "Boy" (line 2).

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title. The "y" of "Boy" (line 2) is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 6, between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Father, father. where are you going
O do not walk so fast,
Speak father, speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost,
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew.
The mire was deep, & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Found,
Object 14 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dark landscape dominated by the trunks of three or four large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous in gender but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the arm of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on rather barren (but perhaps grassy) ground, toward the viewer. The child raises his right arm to hold the adult's arm. The adult has a lighted ring around his head that suggests a halo; the child appears to wear a hat, which also might suggest a halo. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

component.illusobjdesc: A haloed, long-haired adult figure in a high-waisted long gown—visually ambiguous in gender though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 5-7) suggests that he is male—walks beside a boy whose arm he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. His halo exudes several spiky beams of dark radiance, the lower of which tend to merge with the dark background. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short and curly hair, a hat that suggests a halo, and perhaps shoes walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed and haloed adult whose arm he holds and up at whom he looks. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees. He steps forward with his right leg. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

A dark landscape—the "lonely dale" (line 9) of the text—is dominated by three or four large and ominous tree trunks—two or three left and one right—without visible leaves or other vegetation except for the suggestion of grass below and two areas of green wash directly behind the child that suggest bushes or other indeterminate plants. The trunks arch to create a kind of dark tunnel in which the two figures walk.
The darkness suggests that the time is still the "night" (line 7) specified in "The Little Boy lost" (object 13, line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is displayed against a background colored to suggest the sky, especially behind and below the text; its rosy tint, especially behind line 3, may suggest sunrise or sunset. A gowned, long-haired angelic spirit flies or hovers with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. Other than her outline, she blends in with the area of sky behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin, and another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned, long-haired angelic spirit, probably female, hovers with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. This may be the child's "mother" (line 8) to whom he is led.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" (line 2) extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "Found" is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward (with a single leaf) into the space below the poem.
The text is displayed against a background colored to suggest the sky, especially behind and below the text; its rosy tint, especially behind line 3, may suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Led by the wand'ring light,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white.
He kissed the child & by the hand led
And to his mother brought,
Who in sorrow pale. thro' the lonely dale
Her little boy weeping sought.

desc.objtitle:
Laughing Song,
Object 15 (Bentley 15, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation bordered by sky across the top. Five figures—one of which, second from left, is somewhat difficult to discern—sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them stands an eighth figure, a male in tights. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all but one of the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The figure on the near side of the table on the left and the central standing figure face away from the viewer; the figure on the right faces to the left. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 3, 7, 11-12). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the border of sky and by the shadows(?) on the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center is a short-haired male in tights standing poised and erect facing away from the viewer. His legs are spread; his right leg is straight, his left is extended left, the foot held with its toes pointed. His arms are bent and raised vertically. In his right hand is a wine glass or cup, in his left a hat with a plume. In the context of the poem his actions suggest that he may be singing.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far left is a female in a long gown; her hair appears to be short, but possibly drawn into a bun. Her left leg is extended forward and her foot is visible; her right leg is drawn back under her. Her right arm is extended to hold a glass that rests on the table. Her left arm rests on the back of her chair, and her body is twisted counterclockwise as if to face the female across the table from her.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far right is a short-haired male in tights. His left leg is extended forward and his foot is visible; his right leg is drawn back under him. His right arm is extended along the table surface to hold a glass; only the upper part of his left arm is visible near the back of the chair. His lower body faces left, with his torso facing forward and his head twisted clockwise to face the two females across the table.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from left, difficult to discern in the present copy, is the upper body and head of a seated figure just above the right shoulder of the woman seated in a chair on the viewer's side of the table.
Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure at far left seems to be a female in a hat with a round brim.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Third from the left is a male or female— with hair that may be long or short, clothes that may be tights or a dress. The figure's head is turned right and tilted up. The right arm is raised to 45 degrees, the left bent at the elbow.
Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the right is a female in a high- waisted gown. Her hair is either short or pulled back. She faces forward.

Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure on the far right has her right arm extended on the table, faces forward, and wears a large hat. At the end of her outstretched right arm the figure holds a glass that rests on the table. A bit of curly hair emerges just below the brim of her hat.

Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Though the vegetation is not clearly defined, the text mentions "meadows" and "green woods" (lines 7, 3). There may be a tree trunk far right.

The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the border of sky and by the shadows on the ground.
