The border of sky at the top of the illustration is tinted with black, gold, and purple wash, suggesting night, sunrise, or sunset. The shadows extend across the illustration’s bottom margin, appear in front of the table (bottom-center), and also appear behind each chair in the foreground, on the left and right.

In front of the table, near each end, two figures sit in symmetrically-placed chairs turned parallel with the table. The chairs have backs and rear legs integrated into a single convex curve. The front legs of the chair on the right curve forward to balance the curve of the rear legs.
Four figures hold drinking glasses. Three rest on the table; the fourth is in the right hand of the central standing figure. Rosy tinting suggesting wine is visible in the three rightmost glasses.
There is a plumed hat with a round brim in the left hand of the central standing figure. The two women at far left and far right sitting behind the table also have on round- brimmed hats.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decoration is marginal rather than strictly interlinear. Numerous birds, especially in the bottom margin, ornament areas around the text. There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing" (line 2), and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines (lines 13-14) and across the bottom. Curving lines left of the second stanza (lines 7-10), and less certainly a few fragments left of the first stanza (lines 3-6), hint at vines. The text area is colored to suggest a cloudy(?) sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The text area is colored to suggest a cloudy(?) sky. Dark blue wash at the bottom left, rosy wash at the bottom right, and light yellow wash that begins behind line 11 and grows more golden as it extends upward, all suggest sunrise or sunset.

Several birds of various sizes perch and fly on and among the vegetation. Around the title, to the left a bird with outspread wings ascends vertically; another glides over "Song" (line 2); and at the right a third dives. In the right margin, after "shade" (line 11), a tiny bird ascends steeply, with what may be two other birds beside it. Across the bottom of the plate are seven others (left to right): two flying above the vine, with outspread wings and forked tails, the right one ascending; below the vine a third, descending; a fourth, with forked tail, perching on the vine; to its right, above the vine a fifth bird flying, and below the vine, a sixth ascending and, finally, a seventh perching with wings raised.

There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing" (line 2), and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines (lines 13-14) and across the bottom. Curving lines left of the second stanza (lines 7-10), and less certainly a few fragments left of the first stanza (lines 3-6), hint at vines.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
When Mary and Susan and Emily,
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He,
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,
To sing the sweet chorus of Ha, Ha, He.

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG,
Object 16 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The colors of the background suggest a sky with perhaps a cloudy area behind the text to set it off. There are three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title (line 2); five in the left margin; and four in the right.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the letters of the title (line 2): what looks like a piper, facing left, playing as he leans against the left side of the "A"; a figure, probably facing right, sitting inside the "C" (clearer in other copies); and a figure standing, facing forward, inside the "D."
A piper plays his pipe as he leans against the letter "A" in the title (line 2).

There are five figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a gowned woman, standing with her arm raised vertically beside the second stanza; a tiny leaping(?) or flying figure with arms bent upward next to "Hover" (line 12), and just beneath it a sitting, hunched over figure, facing right and possibly holding a book or tablet; a sitting(?) figure that may be facing forward and holding a tendril of vegetation beside the fifth stanza; and, beside the sixth stanza, a figure facing right, with its arm raised.
The seated figure left of lines 13-14 may be holding a book or tablet.

There are four(?) figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a figure sitting with head down on the vegetation to the right of "streams" (line 5); a gowned female(?), her arm extended and her body horizontal, lying on or hovering in front of the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 6 and 7; a figure walking right at the end of lines 17-18; and, just above it, a figure lying or sitting on a curve of the vegetation. This last figure appears to be facing left, with one arm drawn back for support and one leg bent at the knee.

Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation of various sorts interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. But the vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title (line 2) contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.

The background colors on the plate suggest sky with perhaps a cloudy area behind the text to set it off. Dark blue wash in the top left corner and near the center of the right margin, and rosy wash in the bottom right corner, suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Sweet dreams form a shade,
O'er my lovely infants head,
Sweet dreams of pleasant streams,
By happy silent moony beams
Sweet sleep with soft down.
Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Sweet sleep Angel mild,
Hover o'er my happy child.
Sweet smiles in the night,
Hover over my delight.
Sweet smiles Mothers smiles
All the livelong night beguiles.
Sweet moans. dovelike sighs,
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
Sweet moans. sweeter smiles,
All the dovelike moans beguiles.
Sleep sleep happy child.
All creation slept and smil'd,
Sleep sleep. happy sleep,
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Sweet babe in thy face.
Holy image I can trace.
Sweet babe once like thee.
Thy maker lay and wept for me

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG (continued),
Object 17 (Bentley 17, Erdman 17, Keynes 17)

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and cap or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle that stands on rockers. Her arms may be folded across her chest, perhaps in an attitude of prayer. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ (object 16, stanza 6; object 17, stanzas 1-2): "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8). The cradle extends to the left of the chair. A carpet with an intricate pattern covers the floor, and dark fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and cap or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right and looks at the infant; her arms may be folded across her chest, perhaps in an attitude of prayer.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ (object 16, stanza 6; object 17, stanzas 1-2): "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8). The child's mouth may be slightly open.
The infant sleeps beneath a blanket and/or sheet. The configuration of the pillow suggests a halo.

An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle. The cradle has handles (visible on the front and back edges), a hood that arches over the infant's head, and rockers (one visible beneath the cradle). The left end of the cradle extends left of the chair.

A carpet with an intricate pattern covers the floor. A shadow appears on the floor beneath the cradle far left and another appears behind the cradle, rising upward along the right margin and fading at the top of the cradle.
Dark fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are three or four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 6-7 is a small hovering figure with at least one arm raised horizontally and legs spread; and to the left of lines 8-9 is another small figure, facing left with arms raised vertically, and hovering, running, or standing by one leg on the tendril to the left of “Heavenly” (line 9).

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 6) and the "p" of "peace" (line 9).

In the left margin there are three or four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands, facing right, with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 6-7 is a small hovering figure with at last one arm raised horizontally and legs spread; and to the left of lines 8-9 is another small figure, facing left with arms raised vertically, and hovering, running, or standing by one leg on the tendril to the left of “Heavenly” (line 9).
The slight blue tinting in the upper part of the text area suggests sky.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all,
When he was an infant small.
Thou his image ever see.
Heavenly face that smiles on thee.
Smiles on thee on me on all.
Who became an infant small,
Infant smiles are his own smiles,
Heaven & earth to peace beguiles:

desc.objtitle:
The Divine Image,
Object 18 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a sky-colored background a serpentine plant-like structure with brilliant flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in a small strip of grassy(?) ground, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb until it terminates just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a gowned female with long hair walks right; a second gowned female with long hair floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned, haloed, Christ-like figure stands, with an arm extended, touching the left hand of a nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Yellow wash at the top left corner (the border of which is marked by the floating female), rosy wash at the top right, and darker blue wash along the left and right margins suggest sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a gowned woman with long hair walks right; her right arm is drawn back behind her. Her left arm is at her side and she may be holding an object in her left hand, possibly a pitcher. She may also hold something, possibly a large jar, in her right arm. Another gowned female with long hair hovers behind her, pointing and facing right.
Two gowned(?) figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right, a haloed Christ-like figure in a high-waisted gown stands and faces left; beams of radiance emanate leftward from his halo, and with an extended arm, he touches the left hand of a short-haired, nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Her body faces forward, and her head appears to be turned slightly to the right and down. The nude male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve.

A serpentine plant-like structure with brilliant flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of leaves that dangles just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.
There would appear to be grassy(?) ground just above the bottom margin of the plate.

The margins are colored to suggest the sky, giving way in the center to a light area of cloud, which serves as a background to the text. Yellow wash at the top left corner (the border of which is marked by the floating female), rosy wash at the top right, and darker blue wash along the left and right margins suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
All pray in their distress:
And to these virtues of delight
Return their thankfulness.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is God our father dear:
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
Pity, a human face:
And Love, the human form divine.
And Peace. the human dress.
Then every man of every clime,
That prays in his distress,
Prays to the human form divine
Love Mercy Pity Peace,
And all must love the human form.
In heathen, turk or jew,
Where Mercy. Love & Pity dwell,
There God is dwelling too.

desc.objtitle:
HOLY THURSDAY,
Object 19 (Bentley 19, Erdman 19, Keynes 19)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats and caps walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats, and each carrying a staff or scepter. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right, and led by a single female(?) figure who is holding a what may be a book. Directly below this book-like object is an indeterminate, green and roughly conical object that may be a small plant, perhaps part of a hedge. The girls wear dresses with aprons. The figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-6). Each boy wears a green, blue, or rosy uniform, and each girl wears a white, blue, or green dress. Together, the girls cast a strip of shadow on the ground below them. The brown tint to this ground beneath the girls suggests grassless earth. Yellow and blue wash behind the procession of girls, and blue and rosy wash behind the procession of boys, suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset. Tall brown objects that may be tree trunks form the left and right borders of the girls’ illustration, casting additional shadows along the bottom margin and terminating when they reach the text area.

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats and caps walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 4 and 6).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, and each holding a staff or scepter. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 6).
Both beadles at the head of the procession hold a staff or scepter, the "wands" (line 6) of the text.

Seven pairs of girls walk left, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear uniform dresses with aprons. They may be wearing hats or head coverings of some sort. Their positions are not always clear; girls in the fourth and fifth pairs from the right gesture with their hands. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-6).
The procession of girls is led by a single gowned figure, probably female, who may be holding an object, probably a book. The figure appears to be wearing a wig or cap.
The robed figure who is leading the procession may be wearing a cap or wig and holding an object, probably a book.

Tall brown objects that may be tree trunks form the left and right borders of the girls’ illustration, casting additional shadows along the bottom margin and terminating when they reach the text area.

The procession of girls casts a strip of shadow on the ground below it. The brown tint to this ground beneath the girls suggests grassless earth. Tall brown objects that may be tree trunks, forming the left and right borders of the girls’ illustration, cast additional shadows along the bottom margin.
Yellow and blue wash behind the procession of girls, and blue and rosy wash behind the procession of boys, suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 2]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 7) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 11). Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird perching on a vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY" [line 2]) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a tiny human figure, running or hovering with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 11. Some of the decorations are suggestive of human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY" [line 2]) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

There are birds beneath "into the" in line 7—flying to the right—and beneath "you drive" in line 15—perching and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 2]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird or human figure. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY" [line 2]) but are equally likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
(snow
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door.

desc.objtitle:
Night,
Object 20 (Bentley 20, Erdman 20, Keynes 20)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is rooted at the top of a hill or mound near the bottom right margin; its branches cross behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate and terminates in the top right corner. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps where the tree bends left, is unclear. The tree is rooted at bottom right between a river in the foreground and a cave where a lion lies. There are winged angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings outspread at top right, a second sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first, and a third flying (or standing on one leg) just above the lion's den. Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6. There is a small star near the right margin, below and to the right of the vine’s bottommost leaf. In the left margin are other figures and objects (bottom to top): a gowned figure, standing on the ground and facing forward; just above that, a hovering figure; another, arms raised vertically, either hovering or standing on a curved marking that may indicate a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (object 20, line 14; object 21, line 7). Above the top figure on the left, beside line 6, is another sphere (the sun or moon?); scattered across this same space in the left margin are four stars and six dots that may also be stars. The sky and the earth are dark in places, with lighter areas behind the title and text area; the coloring and stars suggest night.

component.illusobjdesc: There are winged, gowned angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings outspread at top right, a second, facing right, sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first, and a third, with arms raised horizontally, flying (or standing on one leg) just above the lion's den.
Opposite "mine" at the end of line 6, two birds perch on a branch of the right-margin tree.

In the left margin are other figures (bottom to top): one gowned, standing on the ground and facing forward; just above that, a hovering figure with one arm raised; another, arms raised vertically, either hovering or standing on a curved marking that may indicate a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (object 20, line 14; object 21, line 7).

Rooted at bottom right, a slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is rooted at the top of a hill or mound near the bottom right margin; its branches cross behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the tree continues up the right side of the plate and terminates in the top right corner. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps where the tree bends left, is unclear. There may be a tree or vine growing in the lower left margin just left of the standing figure.

A strip of grass runs across the bottom of the plate; at right it covers a hill or bank. A strip of shadow runs across the top of this grass, reaching from the standing figure in the bottom left corner to the hill or bank.
In the grass-covered hill, mound, or bank at right is a cave.
A lion lies facing forward in a cave.
A river runs across the foreground.
The sky is blue but somber, suggesting night.

In the left margin are at least one and perhaps two small circular spheres, one above the figures and the other (a more ambiguous marking) beneath the feet of the second figure from the top. One may be the moon and the other the sun. Between the two spheres are scattered four stars and six dots that may also be stars.
There is a single star near the right margin, below and to the right of the vine’s bottommost leaf.

lg.l: Night

component.illusobjdesc: The style of lettering in the title integrates it into the tree.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west.
The evening star does shine.
The birds are silent in their nest.
And I must seek for mine,
The moon like a flower.
In heavens high bower;
With silent delight.
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves,
Where flocks have took delight;
Where lambs have nibbled, silent moves
The feet of angels bright;
Unseen they pour blessing,
And joy without ceasing,
On each bud and blossom,
And each sleeping bosom.
They look in every thoughtless nest,
Where birds are coverd warm;
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm;
If they see any weeping.
That should have been sleeping
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

l.note: In Copy U, only fragments of the catchword "When" printed.

desc.objtitle:
Night (continued),
Object 21 (Bentley 21, Erdman 21, Keynes 21)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text of the poem appears to be etched in a sky-colored area that has been opened for the purpose over the branches of a large tree whose trunk, entwined by a leafy vine, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Beyond the tips of the branches is a vertical strip of night sky with four large stars. On the ground, between a backdrop of trees or other vegetation and a river that runs across the foreground, five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right; the one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left. The upper bodies of the figures in both groups are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (object 20, line 14; object 21, line 7). One of the lights, more probably the one behind the two figures to the right, may be the moon. In the vine-encircled tree trunk in the left margin there are two other gowned female figures, perhaps more of the angels mentioned in the text; they are without haloes.

component.illusobjdesc: Five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To their left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right; the one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left. The upper bodies of the figures in both groups are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (object 20, line 14; object 21, line 7).

In the vine-encircled tree trunk in the left margin there are two other gowned female figures, perhaps more of the angels mentioned in the text, though they are without haloes. The bottom figure, beside the last stanza, has one arm raised vertically. The top figure, beside the first stanza, has an arm (the left?) raised vertically.

The text of the poem appears to be etched in a sky-colored area that has been opened for the purpose over the branches of a large tree whose trunk, entwined by a leafy vine, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Five figures stand on the grass against a backdrop of trees or other vegetation.

A strip of night sky in the right margin lightens considerably to the left, underneath the branches. The lighter area, colored as if to suggest sky and clouds, extends upward behind the text and (as it were) over the branches of the tree.

In the night sky are four large stars, all near the right margin: one just beyond the branches to the right of the second stanza; one far to the right of line 18; one far to the right of line 20; and a fourth far to the right of line 21.
A river runs across the foreground in front of the five female figures.

The upper bodies of the figures in both groups at the bottom of the plate are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (object 20, line 14; object 21, line 7). One of the lights, more probably the one on the right, may be the moon.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for prey
They pitying stand and weep;
Seeking to drive their thirst away,
And keep them from the sheep.
But if they rush dreadful;
The angels most heedful,
Recieve each mild spirit.
New worlds to inherit.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold;
And pitying the tender cries.
And walking round the fold:
Saying: wrath by his meekness
And by his health, sickness.
Is driven away,
From our immortal day.
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name.
Grase after thee and weep.
For wash'd in lifes river.
My bright mane for ever.
Shall shine like the gold.
As I guard o'er the fold.

desc.objtitle:
Spring,
Object 22 (Bentley 22, Erdman 22, Keynes 22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sitting on a grassy bank at the left, beneath the branches of a tree that is rooted on the bank behind her, a gowned woman with hair pulled back looks toward a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward a grazing flock of sheep. There is the slight suggestion of a second tree at the left edge of the design. A grassy horizon, with the suggestion of two distant hills or mountains, can be seen behind the sheep. The colors of the sky suggest sunrise or sunset and perhaps clouds. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (object 23, line 9).

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting on a grassy bank at the left, a gowned woman with hair pulled back looks out toward a nude infant—perhaps her own—who she holds in her lap. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

A seated woman holds her(?) short-haired nude infant, who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (object 23, line 9).

A mother and her(?) infant overlook a flock of grazing sheep. In the final stanza of the poem, an infant or child speaks to a "Little Lamb" (object 23, line 9), and though there is no "little" lamb visible in the design, one of the animals does raise its head. The sheep far right is a ram with horns.
The colors of the sky suggest sunrise or sunset and perhaps clouds.

The design is partially framed by a tree whose large trunk is rooted in a grassy bank at the left. Its leafy branches arch over a seated woman and her infant. There is the slight suggestion of a second tree at the left edge of the design. Low hills, or perhaps two distant mountains, define the horizon behind the sheep.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is displayed against a background washed to suggest the sky, with a strip of ground across the bottom. Up the left edge grows a vine-like plant with a distinctly spiky edge. The remaining decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. Vine-like extensions of the "S" of "Spring" curl up to its left; dangle (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring" (line 2); curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and possibly a grain tassel to the right of lines 2-3; and curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. Two winged angels occupy this vegetation, one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe, the other reclining on one arm.

component.illusobjdesc: Two winged angels with obscure features occupy the vegetation to the right of the text: one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe opposite line 4; the other, wings outspread, reclining on one arm opposite line 12. Both angels may be gowned; the angel's face is turned to the left.

Up the left edge grows a vine-like plant with a distinctly spiky edge. The remaining decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. Vine-like extensions of the "S" of "Spring" curl up to its left; dangle (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text; and connect that initial letter of the title with the initial letter of the poem. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring" (line 2); curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, one loopy tendril, and possibly a grain tassel to the right of lines 2-3; and curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate.

The text is displayed against a background washed to suggest the sky. The slightly rosy area to the right of the title, and the dark blue area at the bottom left corner, hint at sunrise or sunset. The lighter area behind the text suggests a cloud.

lg.l: Sound the Flute!
Now it's mute.
Birds delight
Day and Night.
Nightingale
In the dale
Lark in Sky
Merrily(Year
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the
Little Boy
Full of joy.

desc.objtitle:
Spring (continued),
Object 23 (Bentley 23, Erdman 23, Keynes 23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with curly hair and halo reclines on a strip of grass behind a river that runs across the foreground. With both hands the infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the infant. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 9). The background, colored to suggest the sky at sunrise or sunset, and perhaps with clouds behind the second stanza, helps to integrate the plate into a single design, though the decorative elements in the margins are typical of Blake's interlinear designs (and similar to those on the previous object, where they are divided from the top design). Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words (lines 2, 9) of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom—even across the surface of the water. This lower extension sprouts an additional tendril left of line 10, and this tendril forks left of line 13. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. The lower one originates at the end of line 9; the upper one extends leftward from the upper right margin and may be connected to a strip of spiky green vegetation that runs from this cluster’s point of origin to the top right corner. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, to the right of lines 13-15, below the end of line 8, and to the right of lines 3-4.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with short, curly hair and halo reclines, with his left leg crossed over his extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand he touches the neck of a lamb to the left; with his right he touches the back of the sheep. The two of them look at each other. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 9).

Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around her. Her body may be twisting away from the viewer.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.
An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. One sheep, with its head turned toward them, lies to the left and another to the right.

The background helps to integrate the plate into a single design, though the decorative elements in the margins are typical of Blake's interlinear designs (and similar to those on the previous object, where they are divided from the top design). Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words (lines 2, 9) of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom—even across the surface of the water. This lower extension sprouts an additional tendril left of line 10, and this tendril forks left of line 13. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. The lower one originates at the end of line 9; the upper one extends leftward from the upper right margin and may be connected to a strip of spiky green vegetation that runs from this cluster’s point of origin to the top right corner. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, as well as to the right of lines 3-4, below the last two words in line 8, and to the right of lines 14-16.
A river runs in front of the strip of grass upon which the infant reclines.
The sheep and child lie on grass.

The background, colored to suggest the sky, possibly with clouds behind the second stanza, helps to integrate the plate into a single design. Rosy tinting and dark blue wash at the top right, and also surrounding the infant and sheep, suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Little Girl
Sweet and small.
Cock does crow
So do you.
Merry voice
Infant noise
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the Year.
Little Lamb
Here I am,
Come and lick
My white neck.
Let me pull
Your soft Wool.
Let me kiss
Your soft face.Year
Merrily Merrily we welcome in the

desc.objtitle:
Nurse's Song Nurses Song,
Object 24 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Beneath the text and dense interlinear vegetation comprising most of the plate, seven children—four boys and two, probably three, girls—hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle under the limb of a tree with a few leaves. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title, sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. The tree has two major branches: the right branch extends straight to the right (above the nurse and children), and the left branch extends up the left margin to the top of the illustration, sprouting a loopy vine beside the last stanza that extends upward, wraps around the first stanza, and apparently merges with the embellishments surrounding the title. This latter branch may also sprout more of these embellishments, left of the title. These two branches and the vine partially frame the text area. To the right is a second tree, slimmer and more obviously leafy, with a vine around its lower trunk. There are "hills" (line 14) in the background and shadows across the foreground. In front of the shadows, a river runs along the bottom margin. The sky above the hills on the left and behind the text area is colored to suggest a sky at sunset (as indicated by line 7).

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: the two children furthest left (a girl[?] and a short-haired boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right with legs outspread; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls have on gowns; all the boys wear tight-fitting garments. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 17) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree with two major branches. Its right branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. Its left branch, with a few leaves near the top, extends up the left margin to the top of the illustration, sprouting a loopy vine beside the last stanza that extends upward, wraps around the first stanza, and apparently merges with the embellishments surrounding the title. This latter branch may also sprout more of these embellishments, left of the title. These two branches and the vine partially frame the text area. On the right is a second tree, slimmer, with more leafy branches visible and a vine climbing up its trunk. Between the trees is "the green" of line 3.

There are "hills" (line 14) in the background, shadows across the foreground. The colors of the sky just above the hills on the left and behind the text area suggest that the time is dusk, as indicated in the text (line 7).
A river runs along the bottom margin, in front of shadows.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g" (line 2). There are also three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration grows from the tree branch in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into the sky/water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting in a curl at the top of the right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u," joining hands with another who reaches up from below; one leaning against the "S" of "Song"; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?) on the leafy structure at the end of line 6. Between the lines there are a few birdlike shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," one climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, in a curl at the top of the right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward and joining hands with another who reaches up from below, where he/she is seated, facing left, on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g" (line 2); one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song"; further along the horizontal descender of the "g," two reclining, the one on the left straddling the vegetation; one, right arm raised horizontally and the left arm drawn back for support, reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?) on the leafy structure at the end of line 6.
There are two birdlike shapes above "for it is" in line 11 and another above "hills" in the last line (line 18).

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are also three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration grows from the tree branch in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into the sky/water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
Halfway down the right margin of the plate, the branches of a leafy weeping willow tree arch down into printed areas that may indicate water.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children, the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play. and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd
And all the hills ecchoed

desc.objtitle:
Infant Joy,
Object 25 (Bentley 25, Erdman 25, Keynes 25)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted on a grassy mound at the bottom right of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left—between the grass and the text—and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female with the suggestion of a halo sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her wings is marked with a dot, and around her head is the suggestion of a halo. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one. In the background is a vast expanse of sky with yellow, rosy, and blue areas that suggest a sunrise or (less likely) sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female with the suggestion of a halo sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her wings is marked with a dot, and around her head is the suggestion of a halo. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7).

Rooted on a grassy mound at the bottom right of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left—between the grass and the text—and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.
The ground below the plant rises into a slight mound.
In the background is a vast expanse of sky with yellow, rosy, and blue areas that suggest a sunrise or (less likely) sunset.

lg.l: I have no name
I am but two days old.__
What shall I call thee?
I happy am
Joy is my name.__
Sweet joy befall thee!
Pretty joy!
Sweet joy but two days old.
Sweet joy I call thee;
Thou dost smile.
I sing the while
Sweet joy befall thee.

desc.objtitle:
A Dream,
Object 26 (Bentley 26, Erdman 26, Keynes 26)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The coloring of the sky and the presence of several stars in the top margin place the scene at night, as implied in the poem. The lighter coloring behind the text suggests clouds. Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The stanzas are separated by irregular vine-like structures that are sometimes extensions of letters (such as the "I" at the beginning of line 19) or extensions of other vegetation (as between stanzas 4 and 5) or, sometimes, discrete bits. The initial "A" in the title (line 2) sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?) rooted in the strip of ground that begins in the illustration’s bottom right corner and, under “home” (line 22). In front of the tree stands a robed figure, wearing a hat, and holding a staff—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form. He is one of four small and indistinct human figures on the plate. The other three are in the area of the title: lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; sitting, probably reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and floating or flying between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream." The animal life of the poem appears in similarly tiny and indistinct (or questionable) forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) on the vegetation beneath "her" in line 10, and another ant or beetle to the right of line 5; a winged beetle(?) (lines 20-21) flying right of line 19; and a glow-worm (line 16) at the edge of the design after line 6. A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 3.

component.illusobjdesc: In front of the tree in the bottom right corner stands a robed figure, wearing a hat, and holding a staff in his(?) right hand, a lantern(?) in his left—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form.

There are three tiny, indistinct figures in the area of the title: one lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; a second sitting, facing left, probably reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and a third hovering or flying with legs spread apart and arms raised horizontally between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream" (line 2).

The insect life of the poem appears in tiny and indistinct (or questionable) forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) crawling on the vegetation beneath "her" in line 10, and perhaps another to the right of line 5; and perhaps winged beetles (lines 20-21) flying right of line 19 and line 6. The human figure in the lower right corner may be the anthropomorphic form of the glow-worm.
A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 3.

Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The stanzas are separated by irregular vine-like structures that are sometimes extensions of letters (such as the "I" at the beginning of line 19) or extensions of other vegetation (as between stanzas 4 and 5) or, sometimes, discrete bits. The initial "A" in the title (line 2) sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a vine-like extension dangles (making one loop) down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title and down to join the grassy tuft below. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?) rooted in the strip of ground that begins in the illustration’s bottom right corner under “home” (line 22). A vine descends through the left margin and extends below the text just above the bottom margin of the plate.

The coloring of the sky and the presence of several stars in the top margin place the scene at night, as implied in the poem. The lighter coloring behind the text suggests clouds. There are three stars in the title area: one left of the "A," one between the “A” and the “D,” and one to the right of the “D” (above the “r”).
The watchman in the lower right corner may be holding a staff in his right hand and a lantern in his left. He seems to be wearing a hat.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade.
O'er my Angel-guarded bed,
That an Emmet lost it's way
Where on grass methought I lay.
Troubled wilderd and folorn"folorn": i.e., "forlorn".
Dark benighted travel-worn,
Over many a tangled spray.
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh.
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
Pitying I drop'd a tear;
But I saw a glow-worm near:
Who replied. What wailing wight
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:
Follow now the beetles hum,
Little wanderer hie thee home.

desc.objtitle:
On Anothers Sorrow On Another's Sorrow,
Object 27 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right in the strip of ground that extends across the bottom edge of the design, grows up the right edge. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 4 (although the coloring in this copy integrates it with adjacent leaves), 7, and 13. Two or three more birds, also rendered ambiguous by their coloring, may perch on the branch beside line 6. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable (line 2). A yellow sky provides the background along the top half of the right margin and across the top of the plate; blue sky provides the background for the left margin and lower half of the right margin; the area behind the text is also yellow, with rosy streaks that suggest clouds at sunrise or sunset. Against the sky on the left is a lattice of bare branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. There are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. At the base of the trees in the left margin, a figure playing a pipe stands against the right tree; at the piper's feet is an indistinct shape (possibly a dog in other copies). A second figure climbs in the branches above—opposite stanza 7. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3 (very lightly printed and hard to make out in this copy), raises his arms as if in supplication, and a fourth, gowned, opposite stanza 1, does the same.

component.illusobjdesc: There are four figures in the left margin. At the base of the trees in the left margin, a figure playing a pipe stands against the right tree. A second figure is climbing in the branches above—opposite stanza 7. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3 (very lightly printed in this copy), raises his arms as if in supplication, and a fourth, gowned, opposite stanza 1, does the same.
An indistinct shape, possibly a dog, sits(?) at the feet of the piper in the lower left corner of the plate; it looks up, perhaps listening to the piper play.

A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Three other birds fly to the right of lines 4 (although the coloring in this copy integrates it with adjacent leaves), 7, and 13. Two or three more birds, also rendered ambiguous by their coloring, may perch on the branch beside line 6.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right in the strip of ground that extends across the bottom edge of the design, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. In the left margin is a lattice of bare branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. There are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.

A yellow sky provides the background along the top half of the right margin and across the top of the plate; blue sky provides the background for the left margin and lower half of the right margin; the area behind the text is also yellow, with rosy streaks that suggest clouds at sunrise or sunset.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe and appears to be wearing a hat.

lg.l: Can I see anothers woe,
And not be in sorrow too.
Can I see anothers grief.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child.
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
Pouring pity in their breast.
And not sit the cradle near
Weeping tear on infants tear.
And not sit both night & day,
Wiping all our tears away.
O! no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all;
He becomes an infant small.
He becomes a man of woe:
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not, thou canst sigh a sigh
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tearThe “e,” “a,” and “r” of “tear” printed very lightly and are difficult to see in this copy.
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan

desc.objtitle:
Frontispiece to Songs of Experience,
Object 28 (Bentley 28, Erdman 28, Keynes 28)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male in colored, semi-transparent tights walks forward, right leg first. Given the setting and the position of the plate in sequence, he is probably the shepherd-piper of the frontispiece to *Innocence*, but he has no pipe. Sitting on his head (or held in front of it), legs dangling either side of his face, is a cherubic, winged angel who is nude, with short hair, and presumably male. The two hold each other's hands. Both figures look straight at the viewer. The environment is pastoral. There are grassy fields in front with hills in the background; sheep graze behind the two figures. A large tree dominates the right side of the design; its leafy branches arch across the top. A short, leafy vine or ivy grows in front of this tree. A second tree behind the sheep on the left helps frame the design. The treatment of the sky suggests sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting on the head (or held and hovering in front of it) of a male shepherd in tights is a cherubic, winged infant angel who is nude, with short hair, and presumably male. He raises his arms horizontally to hold the hands of the shepherd, and his legs dangle either side of the shepherd's face. Both figures look straight out at the viewer.

A young male in colored, semi-transparent tights with a plunging neckline and collar walks forward, right leg first. His left foot is poised on tiptoe. His arms are bent upward to hold the hands of the infant angel who sits on (or hovers in front of) his head. He, like the angel, looks directly out at the viewer. Given the setting and the position of the plate in sequence, the young male seems to be the shepherd-piper of the frontispiece to *Innocence*, but he has no pipe.
Sheep graze behind the two figures.

There are grassy fields in front with hills behind. A large tree dominates the right side of the design; its leafy branches arch across the top. A short, leafy vine or ivy grows in front of this tree. A second tree behind the sheep on the left helps frame the design.
In the background are grassy fields and, behind them, hills.
The treatment of the sky suggests sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
Title Page for Songs of Experience,
Object 29 (Bentley 29, Erdman 29, Keynes 29)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a composition dominated by strict verticals and horizontals, a young short-haired male (behind) and young gowned female (in front) with her hair pulled back in a bun bend over two dead(?) bodies, an old, bearded, gowned male (in front) and a gowned female, possibly wearing a cap of some sort (behind), who are laid out on a draped table (possibly a bier) that extends from the left to right edge of the design. The two mourners are seen in profile facing left, their heads looking down toward the bodies, and holding their hands to their heads in gestures of distress, perhaps crying or in prayer. The corpses are arranged with their heads resting on pillows at left. The visible (right) arm of the male is at his side. Because of their lack of color, the two might be taken for tomb effigies. In the background is a paneled wall or partition flanked by pilasters—a cemetery wall, tomb, or church interior; on the right pilaster appears the ostensible date of publication, "1794" (line 5). Shadows fall toward the left on each pilaster and, on the right, onto the legs of the supine bodies, the gowned female, and the ground right of her feet. Above the background structure, in a space colored to suggest sky at sunrise or sunset, is the title, with its first and third words in block letters. In a rectangle (suggestive of a grave?) below the feet of the mourning female is more publication information. Along the right margin and in the top right corner are what may be curtains or, more likely in light of the branches, parts of trees. Taken together, the bottom rectangle and the tree-like border along the right margin suggest that the scene is set out of doors, perhaps at graveside.

component.illusobjdesc: A young short-haired male (behind) and young gowned female (in front) with her hair pulled back in a bun bend over two dead(?) bodies laid out on a draped table. The male is clothed, at least, with a shirt (the lower half of his body is not pictured). The two mourners are seen in profile facing left, holding their heads down and holding their hands to their faces in gestures of distress, perhaps crying (though no tears are visible) or praying. The female stands with her weight on her right leg, her left leg extended behind. They may be the children of the dead couple.

Two dead(?) bodies, an old, bearded, gowned male (in front) and a gowned female, possibly wearing a cap of some sort (behind), are laid out rigidly on a draped table or bier that extends from the left to right edge of the design. The bodies are arranged horizontally with their heads resting on pillows at left. The visible (right) arm of the male is at his side. Because of their lack of color, the two might be taken for tomb effigies.

In a rectangle below the feet of the mourning female, colored in a way that may suggest an open grave, is more publication information. The grave-like rectangle and the tree-like border along the right margin suggest that the scene is out of doors, perhaps at graveside.

Along the right margin and in the top right corner are what may be curtains or, more likely in light of the branches, parts of trees. Taken together, the grave-like rectangle and the tree-like border along the right margin suggest that the scene is set out of doors, perhaps at graveside.
In the background is a paneled wall or partition flanked by pilasters—a graveyard wall, tomb, or church interior. On the right pilaster appears the ostensible date of publication, "1794" (line 5).
A shadow falls toward the left across the left pilaster behind the heads of the two supine bodies.
A shadow falls toward the left across the right pilaster and onto the legs of the supine bodies, the gowned female, and on the ground right of her feet.
Above a wall, in a cloudy sky with rosy coloring suggestive of sunrise or sunset, is the title, with its first and third words in block letters.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Despite the rather inorganic block capital letters, the letters of the first word of the title have ornamental extensions. The initial "S" (line 2) sprouts a vine-like extension from its top, a cluster of flowers or tendrils with leaves that extend across the first three letters; from the bottom of the "S" another tendril, with one loop, terminates in a flower or large leaf. An extension from the top of the "G" divides left into leafy branches, to the right into a pair of flowers or leaves. The top of the final "S" sends out a tendril with many small loops that curves right and down below the letter toward the head of the floating figure. The "of" (line 3) has two extensions with several branches and leaves, probably ivy. Three human figures are associated with the text of the title. Standing on an extension at the bottom of the initial "S" is a gowned figure with arm raised. Two figures flank "of": to the left (facing right) hovers a gowned female with long hair that streams behind her in a kind of tail, her arm extended, and to the right (facing left) hovers a short-haired male, nude or wearing tights, his left arm raised and his left leg extended backward, as if leaping in mid-air.

component.illusobjdesc: Three human figures are associated with the text of the title. Standing on an extension at the bottom of the initial "S" (line 2) is a gowned figure with arm raised and probably facing right. Two figures flank "of": to the left (facing right) hovers a gowned female with long hair that streams behind her in a kind of tail, her arm extended, and to the right (facing left) hovers a short-haired male, nude or wearing tights, his left arm raised and his left leg extended backward, as if leaping in mid-air.

The "of" (line 3) has two extensions with several branches and leaves, probably ivy.

desc.objtitle:
Introduction,
Object 30 (Bentley 30, Erdman 30, Keynes 30)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a cloud in a night sky with fifteen stars and a small dot, far right of line 11, that may be a sixteenth star. The text appears on the cloud. Below the text, on the bottom of the same cloud, a nude female with long hair reclines on her left side on a couch that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion or pillow beneath her elbow. She is seen from behind, with her head turned to the right. She rests on her left arm and draws her left leg up under her right, which is fully extended. She may be the "Earth" addressed by "the voice of the Bard" (lines 3, 13). There is a small separate cloud at bottom left.

component.illusobjdesc: Below the text, on the bottom of a cloud, a nude female with long hair reclines on her left side on a couch that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion beneath her elbow. She is seen from behind, with her head turned to the right. She rests on her left arm and draws her left leg up under her right, which is fully extended. She may be the "Earth" addressed by "the voice of the Bard" (lines 3, 13).
A nude female figure reclines on a couch that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion or pillow beneath her elbow.
The design is dominated by clouds in a night sky with fifteen stars and a small dot, far right of line 11, that may be a sixteenth star. At bottom left there is a small separate cloud.

lg.l: Hear the voice of the Bard!
Who Present, Past, & Future sees
Whose ears have heard,
The Holy Word,
That walk'd among the ancient trees.
Calling the lapsed Soul
And weeping in the evening dew:
That might controll.
The starry pole;
And fallen fallen light renew!
O Earth O Earth return!
Arise from out the dewy grass;
Night is worn,
And the morn
Rises from the slumberous mass,
Turn away no more:
Why wilt thou turn away
The starry floor
The watry shore
Is giv'n thee till the break of day.

desc.objtitle:
EARTH'S Answer,
Object 31 (Bentley 31, Erdman 31, Keynes 31)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A trunk-like border, probably a tree rooted in the grassy ground at the bottom left corner, extends up the left margin, continues across the top margin, and descends in the right margin to fade into the ground at the bottom right corner. The border’s jagged edges in the right margin suggest leaves, or perhaps imply that other vegetation has replaced the tree. To the right of the left marginal border is a leafy vine that frames the text area on its left and top sides, wraps around the right of lines 2-5, and terminates in the space following the short lines 5 and 6. This vine appears to be an extension of the serpent’s tail at the bottom left corner of the plate, though the two are probably distinct. Independent vines or branches decorate the top right corner of the plate and separate all of the stanzas. A vine with a loop grows from the initial letter in line 7; one of its branches descends left of the second stanza, while the other grows horizontally between the first and second stanzas. Another, possibly growing from the "f" of "of" in line 12, bears leaves and a large cluster of grapes right of line 12 before extending upward and to the left, completing the divide between the first two stanzas. Another vine, possibly growing from the top of the initial "S" in line 13, separates the second and third stanzas. One of this vine’s tendrils grows leftward and down the left margin; the other descends in serpentine leaves through the right margin of and into the spaces between the third, fourth, and fifth stanzas. Across the bottom an open-mouthed serpent crawls to the right across the grass. The text appears over a large expanse of rosy, golden, and possibly cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Across the bottom a serpent slithers to the right across the grass. Its mouth is open and its tongue is visible. It has a single loop near its tail.

The border’s jagged edges in the right margin suggest leaves, or perhaps imply that other vegetation has replaced the tree. To the right of the left marginal border is a leafy vine that frames the text area on its left and top sides, wraps around the right of lines 2-5, and terminates in the space following the short lines 5 and 6. This vine appears to be an extension of the serpent’s tail at the bottom left corner of the plate, though the two are probably distinct.
The text appears over a large expanse of rosy, golden, and possibly cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

Another, possibly growing from the "f" of "of" in line 12, has many loops on one branch and, on another, bears leaves and a large cluster of grapes right of line 12 before extending upward and to the left, completing the divide between the first two stanzas. Another vine, possibly growing from the top of the initial "S" in line 13, separates the second and third stanzas. One of this vine’s tendrils grows leftward and down the left margin; the other descends in serpentine leaves through the right margin of and into the spaces between the third, fourth, and fifth stanzas.

Another, possibly growing from the "f" of "of" in line 12, has many loops on one branch and, on another, bears leaves and a large cluster of grapes right of line 12 before extending upward and to the left, completing the divide between the first two stanzas.
