One of this vine’s tendrils grows leftward and down the left margin; the other descends in serpentine leaves through the right margin of and into the spaces between the third, fourth, and fifth stanzas.

lg.l: Earth rais'd up her head,
From the darkness dread & drear.
Her light fled;
Stony dread!
And her locks cover'd with grey despair.
Prison'd on watry shore
Starry Jealousy does keep my den
Cold and hoar
Weeping o'er
I hear the father of the ancient men
Selfish father of men
Cruel jealous selfish fear
Can delight
Chain'd in night
The virgins of youth and morning bear,
Does spring hide its joy
When buds and blossoms grow?
Does the sower?
Sow by night?
Or the plowman in darkness plow?
Break this heavy chain.
That does freeze my bones around
Selfish! vain!
Eternal bane!
That free Love with bondage bound.

desc.objtitle:
The CLOD & the PEBBLE The CLOD & the PEBBLE,
Object 32 (Bentley 32, Erdman 32, Keynes 32)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The cattle mentioned in line 8—four sheep and two oxen—drink water from the "brook" (line 9). A tree grows up the right margin beside the animals; its leafless branches extend across the top of the plate. In the background a dark hill and a strip of sky are visible; the color of the sky suggests sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The cattle mentioned in line 8—four sheep and two oxen—drink water from the "brook" (line 9). The second sheep from the left has the horns of a ram; the other three are probably ewes. Both oxen have U-shaped horns and open eyes.
A tree grows up the right margin beside the animals; its leafless branches extend across the top of the plate.
In the background a dark hill and a strip of sky are visible. The color of the sky suggests sunrise or sunset.
Sheep and oxen drink from a "brook" (line 9).

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a "brook" (line 9) flowing across the bottom of the plate behind the bank in the foreground. A duck sits at left; one frog (center) sits on the river bank, head up and perhaps looking at vegetation or insects(?) flying above, and a second frog (at right) leaps upward and toward the left; on the ground between the frogs crawls a worm. A leafy, vine-like plant grows on the bank between the frogs. A vine with leaves grows just right of the duck and arches to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A duck sits at left.

One frog (center) sits facing right on the river bank, perhaps looking up at vegetation or insects(?) flying above and to the right of its head, and a second frog (at right) with its mouth open leaps upward and to the left. On the ground between them is a worm.
A leafy, vine-like plant grows on the bank between the frogs and continues up the right margin of the text. A vine with leaves grows right of the duck and arches to the right.
There is a "brook" (line 9) flowing across the bottom of the plate behind the bank in the foreground.
Wash in the text area hints at the sky, perhaps with clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The initial letter and the ampersand of the title are ornamented with downward flourishes. Extensions of the initial letter of line 7 help separate the first two stanzas and decorate the area to the left of stanza 2; extensions of the "h" of "seeketh" in line 11 help separate stanzas 2 and 3. The larger spaces of the right margin are filled by the leafy extensions of the plant in the lower illustration.

Extensions of the initial letter of line 7 help separate the first two stanzas and decorate the area to the left of stanza 2; extensions of the "h" of "seeketh" in line 11 help separate stanzas 2 and 3. The right branch extending from this "h" contains a loop near its end. The larger spaces of the right margin are filled by the leafy extensions of the plant in the lower illustration.

lg.l: Love seeketh not Itself to please,
Nor for itself hath any care;
But for another gives its ease.
And builds a Heaven in Hells despair,
So sung a little Clod of Clay,
Trodden with the cattles feet:
But a Pebble of the brook,
Warbled out these metres meet.
Love seeketh only Self to please,
To bind another to Its delight;
Joys in anothers loss of ease,
And builds a Hell in Heavens despite.

desc.objtitle:
HOLY THURSDAY,
Object 33 (Bentley 33, Erdman 33, Keynes 33)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Beneath a tree, a gowned female looks down at a dead(?) child—presumably her own—lying on the ground to the left. In accord with the land described in stanza 3, the natural surroundings are bleak. Though grass is visible, the landscape is otherwise barren: the crags behind the female appear mostly rocky, and the tree in the right margin and overhead has leafless branches. A body of water stretches out behind the two figures. The sky is visible above the hills.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female with her hair in a bun or coiffure stands looking left and down at a dead(?) child—presumably her own—lying on the ground. Her arms appear rigid at her side, and her palms are horizontal, as if in a gesture of grief and horror. Her left foot is visible beneath her gown.
A dead(?) child lies nude(?) on the ground in a supine position with its head to the left. The body is rigid, with at least the right arm close to the child's side and its legs together.
The natural surroundings are bleak. Though grass is visible, the landscape is otherwise barren. The tree in the right margin and overhead has leafless branches.
The crags to the right appear mostly rocky. A body of water, possibly a lake, stretches out behind the two figures. The sky is visible above the hills or mountains.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Scenes of misery continue down the right margin. Opposite stanza 2 is a group of three figures. A gowned female, presumably the mother, is seated with at least one leg drawn up as she holds in her lap a nude child who clings to her shoulder. A second child stands facing them at the left, his head down in his visible hand. Below this group, in the lower right corner, is the nude corpse of another child(?). All the figures are positioned on beds of lush, green vegetation, perhaps giant leaves. There is a bit of spiky vegetation above the dead child at lower right. Left of the text area is a vine that branches off to underline the title and separate stanzas 1 and 2. Left of the title, a prominent leaf or bloom grows from the vine that descends left of the text area. Three similar leaves or flowers sprout on the segment of the vine that separates the title from the first stanza. In the left margin, a tree or vine grows from the ground in the bottom left corner and extends upward, forming a border, until it fades into the top half’s illustration.

component.illusobjdesc: Opposite stanza 2 is a group of three figures on a bed of lush, green vegetation. A gowned female, presumably the mother, with her hair possibly pulled back into a bun, is seated with at least one leg drawn up as she holds in her lap a seated nude child who looks upward and clings to her shoulder. She looks down, perhaps at the child. A second child stands facing them at the left, his head held down in his visible hand. The standing child has on tights and has curly hair.
Positioned with its head nearest the viewer, the nude corpse of a short-haired child lies supine on a bed of vegetation, arms horizontal in an upside-down cruciform posture, legs drawn up.
All the figures are positioned on beds of leaves with grass and other plants along the lower margin. There is a bit of spiky vegetation above the dead child at lower right.
In the left margin, a tree or vine grows from the ground in the bottom left corner and extends upward, forming a border, until it fades into the top half’s illustration.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An independent vine dangling to the left of the text area sends out tendrils that separate the title from the stanzas and the stanzas from one another. In the latter case, the tendrils connect with the leafy vegetation in the right margin. From this vine, a single notable leaf or flower sprouts left of the title, and from it further vegetation extends under the title and sprouts three similar leaves or flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: An independent vine dangling to the left of the text area sends out tendrils that separate the title from the stanzas and the stanzas from one another. In the latter case, the tendrils connect with the leafy vegetation in the right margin. From this vine, a single notable leaf or flower sprouts left of the title. From this leaf’s middle arm grows a sprig that arches under the grass in the illustration and may culminate in three berries. Another tendril of vegetation extends right from this vine; it runs under the title and sprouts three similar leaves or flowers.

lg.l: Is this a holy thing to see.
In a rich and fruitful land,
Babes reducd to misery,
Fed with cold and usurous hand?
Is that trembling cry a song?
Can it be a song of joy?
And so many children poor?
It is a land of poverty!
And their sun does never shine.
And their fields are bleak & bare.
And their ways are fill'd with thorns
It is eternal winter there.
For where-e'er the sun does shine.
And where-e'er the rain does fall;
Babe can never hunger there,
Nor poverty the mind appall.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Girl Lost,
Object 34 (Bentley 34, Erdman 34, Keynes 34)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration is integrated into a full-plate design by virtue of the single strip of ground below and the washes for the sky. The colors of the sky suggest sunset, appropriate to the approach of night recorded in the text, with a dark cloud behind the figures lower right. The design is focused on two human figures standing in an embrace under the arching branches of a tall, slender, vine-entwined willow-like tree in the right margin. A female in a semi-transparent gown looks right as she points upward with her left arm and with her right arm embraces a young male. Her one visible eye is open. He embraces her with both arms. At her feet is a mound of vegetation—apparently a plant with one leaf visible, perhaps an anemone pulsatilla. To the left of the treetop a bird—with a long forked tail and wings spread—ascends. A border of indeterminate vegetation runs up the top half of the right margin and extends leftward across the right half of the top margin. (The prominent but structurally independent[?] vine that fills the left margin is classified here as interlinear decoration.)

component.illusobjdesc: The design is focused on two young human figures standing under a willow. Seen from behind with her left leg extended backward, a female, with her hair pulled back and wearing a transparent gown, looks right as she points upward with her left arm and with her right arm embraces a young, short-haired male wearing tights. Her one visible eye is open. He turns his head forward and embraces her with both arms.

Two figures embrace under the arching branches of a tall, slender, vine-entwined willow-like tree in the right margin. The vine—with numerous leaves or flowers—has two unusually extravagant tendrils to the left of the tree trunk. The lower one arches over the couple beneath and extends nearly to the ground.
On the strip of ground at the feet of the young female is a mound of vegetation—apparently a plant with one leaf visible, perhaps an anemone pulsatilla.
To the left of the treetop a bird—with a long forked tail and wings spread—ascends.
The background is washed to suggest the sky at sunset or twilight, appropriate to the approach of night recorded in the text. The couple lower right is backed by a large, dark cloud.
A border of indeterminate vegetation runs up the top half of the right margin and extends leftward across the right half of the top margin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Independent of the rest of the design—hence here classified as interlinear decoration—an elaborate serpentine vine with leaves and flowers fills the left margin. A serpent-entwined tendril of the vine reinforces the division after the first two stanzas. Two birds, one descending and the other perching on the vine just below the other, are visible to the left of stanzas eight and nine. A vine trails right of the title.

component.illusobjdesc: Independent of the rest of the design—hence classified here with interlinear decoration—an elaborate serpentine vine with leaves and flowers fills the left margin. A serpent-entwined tendril of the vine reinforces the division after the first two stanzas.
A vine trails right of the title.
Two birds, one descending and the other perching on the vine just below, are visible to the left of stanzas eight and nine. At least the flying bird has a long tail.
A serpent is entwined with a tendril that reinforces the division after the first two stanzas. The serpent's head curves back to the left; its mouth is open and its tongue visible.

lg.l: In futurity
I prophetic see.
That the earth from sleep.
(Grave the sentence deep)
Shall arise and seek
For her maker meek;
And the desart wild
Become a garden mild.
In the southern clime,
Where the summers prime.
Never fades away;
Lovely Lyca lay.
Seven summers old
Lovely Lyca told.
She had wanderd long.
Hearing wild birds song,
Sweet sleep come to me
Underneath this tree;
Do father, mother weep.__
"Where can Lyca sleep".
Lost in desart wild
Is your little child.
How can Lyca sleep.
If her mother weep.
If her heart does ake,
Then let Lyca wake;
If my mother sleep,
Lyca shall not weep.
Frowning frowning night,
O'er this desart bright.
Let thy moon arise,
While I close my eyes.
Sleeping Lyca lay;
While the beasts of prey,
Come from caverns deep,
View'd the maid asleep
The kingly lion stood
And the virgin view'd,
Then he gambold round
O'er the hallowd ground:

l.note: In Copy U, only fragments of the letters "pards" in the catchword "Leopards" printed.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Girl Found,
Object 35 (Bentley 35, Erdman 35, Keynes 35)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young(?), gowned female reclines in a forest under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. She may be Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (object 34, line 23). Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background. The sky shows through in the upper part of the design. A slender tree or vine with a few leaves rises in the far left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Under trees, a young(?) gowned female—perhaps identical with her unidentified counterpart on the previous object or perhaps Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (object 34, line 23)—reclines with her weight resting on her braced right arm, her bent left arm folded across her body. Her legs are crossed and her left foot is exposed. Her body faces forward but her head is twisted upward and to the right.

A female reclines in a forest under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background. The tree on the left has a bare branch that extends vertically up the margin and another extending under the last stanza, while the branches of the tree on the right are leafy. A slender tree or vine with a few leaves rises in the far left margin. There may be other, indeterminate vegetation in the background.
The sky is visible in the upper part of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 2) or the "lioness" (line 10) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost" (object 34, line 2), stands on a slightly hilly area of grass beneath an arching tree. The tree is bare except for two leaves on its branch far left. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal. A loopy vine typical of Blake's interlinear decoration but here extending to the tree and rooted at lower left fills the left margin. Blue wash in the background, with white behind the text, suggests a cloudy sky.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 2) or the "lioness" (line 10) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost" (object 34, line 2), stands on a slightly hilly area of grass beneath an arching tree. Its head is turned to the right and raised, echoing the position of the female in the design above.

A lion or tiger stands on a slightly hilly area of grass beneath an arching tree. The tree is bare except for two leaves on its branch far left. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal.
Blue wash in the background, with white behind the text, suggests a cloudy sky.
A loopy vine typical of Blake's interlinear decoration but here extending to the tree and rooted at lower left fills the left margin. It bears a few leaves and flowers.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title (line 14) have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together. The vine in the left margin, though typical of Blake's interlinear decoration, is here extended to the tree in the main design.

component.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title (line 14) have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together.

lg.l: Leopards, tygers play,
Round her as she lay;
While the lion old,
Bow'd his mane of gold,
And her bosom lick.
And upon her neck,
From his eyes of flame,
Ruby tears there came;
While the lioness.
Loos'd her slender dress,
And naked they convey'd
To caves the sleeping maid.
All the night in woe,
Lyca's parents go:
Over vallies deep
While the desarts weep.
Tired and woe-begone.
Hoarse with making moan:
Arm in arm seven days.
They trac'd the desart ways.
Seven nights they sleep.
Among shadows deep:
And dream they see their child
Starv'd in desart wild.
Pale thro' pathless ways
The fancied image strays,

desc.objtitle:
The Little Girl Found (continued),
Object 36 (Bentley 36, Erdman 36, Keynes 36)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On grass at the foot of the entwined trunks of two leafy(?) trees (in turn entwined by leafy vines) in the right margin and near a pair of vines or a sapling and a vine in the left margin, a lion (right) lies close beside a seated infant on the right while a lioness (left) or, less likely, a tiger (both mentioned in the text) lies with a nude infant sitting on her back. A nude female child stands beside them, holding the infant's arm, while a nude young(?) female lies sleeping(?) in front of them. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 29-31) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 23). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child / Among tygers wild" (lines 34-35). The rosy and dark blue background washes suggest areas of sky with a few clouds at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant or child with short and curly hair sits leaning on a lion and looks right toward it. The child is probably male. His right hand rests on or holds the lion's right front leg. Although the child's body faces forward, his shoulders and head are twisted to the right.

A nude, short-haired infant or child, perhaps male, sits on the back of a lioness or tiger. His body faces left toward the front of the animal, and he reaches forward with his right hand as if to hold the animal by its head; but the infant reaches back with the left hand to hold the arm of a girl behind them.

A nude female child with long hair leans left toward an infant or child sitting on a lioness or tiger. With her left hand she reaches to hold the left arm of the infant while her right hand seems to rest on the rear end of the animal. She looks down at the animal; her legs appear to be crossed at the ankles.

A young(?) nude female lies sleeping(?) on her left side facing away from the viewer with her head to the left. Her upper body is twisted to face the ground and her arms are wrapped around her head. Her left leg is drawn up under her, her right leg is extended, and her right foot is visible. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 29-31) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 23). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child / Among tygers wild" (lines 34-35).
On the left a lioness or, less likely, a tiger lies with its body facing left, its head twisted around to look right toward the child on its back.
A lion with a mane lies facing forward with its front paws extended as an infant or child sits next to it.
The entwined trunks of two large and leafy(?) trees (in turn entwined by leafy vines) occupy the right margin.
A pair of vines, one with loops, or a leafless sapling entwined by a leafy vine occupies the left margin.
The forest floor is covered with grass.
The rosy and dark blue background washes suggest areas of sky with a few clouds at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Famish'd. weeping. weak
With hollow piteous shriek
Rising from unrest,
The trembling woman prest,
With feet of weary woe;
She could no further go.
In his arms he bore.
Her arm'd with sorrow sore;
Till before their way,
A couching lion lay.
Turning back was vain,
Soon his heavy mane.
Bore them to the ground;
Then he stalk'd around.
Smelling to his prey.
But their fears allay.
When he licks their hands:
And silent by them stands.
They look upon his eyes
Fill'd with deep surprise;
And wondering behold.
A spirit arm'd in gold.
On his head a crown
On his shoulders down.
Flow'd his golden hair.
Gone was all their care.
Follow me he said,
Weep not for the maid;
In my palace deep,
Lyca lies asleep.
Then they followed,
Where the vision led;
And saw their sleeping child,
Among tygers wild.
To this day they dwell
In a lonely dell
Nor fear the wolvish howl,
Nor the lions growl.

desc.objtitle:
THE Chimney Sweeper,
Object 37 (Bentley 37, Erdman 37, Keynes 37)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The chimney sweeper of the text, a "little black thing among the snow" (line 3), walks down a city street—he is at a corner—bordered by houses. The dark coloring makes him appear dirty, as if sooty from his work. He wears the uniform of the sweep, dark breeches and dark cutaway coat (with tails in other copies)—mourning garb, the "clothes of death" (line 9)—along with shoes or boots and a cap or head covering of some sort. He carries a pack of soot on his back and the brush of his trade in his right hand. The wintry landscape is a bleak gray-white, and diagonal lines indicate falling snow.

component.illusobjdesc: The chimney sweeper of the text, a "little black thing among the snow" (line 3), walks on the sidewalk of a city street; he is at a corner. He walks diagonally forward to the right, right foot first, but turns his face up to the left. The dark coloring makes him appear dirty, as if sooty from his work. He wears the uniform of the sweep, dark breeches and dark cutaway coat (with tails in other copies)—mourning garb, the "clothes of death" (line 9)—along with shoes or boots and a head covering, perhaps a cap. He carries a bag of soot on his back with his left hand and the brush of his trade by his side in his right hand. His mouth may be slightly open, as if "Crying weep, weep" (line 4).
The chimney sweep holds a bag of soot and the brush of his trade.

The bleak wintry scene comprises snow or sleet (represented by diagonal lines and a gray-white landscape) coming from a band of dark clouds just beneath the text. The landscape seems dirty with smoke and/or soot.

The scene is a wintry city street corner. In the background to the left and the foreground right are buildings with pitched roofs—possibly with a window or windows in the former and a door (probably made of wood) in the latter.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions on the "T" of "The" in the title (line 2), the "y" of "Chimney," and the "S" and "p" of "Sweeper" ornament the title area, while similar vegetative decoration—with the additional suggestion of long leaves—fills some of the spaces in the right margin and reinforces the separation between stanzas 2 and 3. Dark blue, purple, and rosy tinting in the text area, with white streaks, suggests a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions on the "T" of "The" in the title (line 2), the "y" of "Chimney," and the "S" and "p" of "Sweeper" ornament the title area, while similar vegetative decoration—with the additional suggestion of long leaves—fills some of the spaces in the right margin and reinforces the separation between stanzas 2 and 3.
Dark blue, purple, and rosy tinting in the text area, with white streaks, suggests a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: A little black thing among the snow:
Crying weep, weep. in notes of woe!
Where are thy father & mother? say?
They are both gone up to the church to pray.
Because I was happy upon the heath,
And smil'd among the winters snow:
They clothed me in the clothes of death.
And taught me to sing the notes of woe.
And because I am happy. & dance & sing.
They think they have done me no injury;
And are gone to praise God & his Priest & King
Who make up a heaven of our misery.

desc.objtitle:
NURSES Song Nurse's Song,
Object 38 (Bentley 38, Erdman 38, Keynes 38)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In an open doorway framed by leafy grapevines bearing clusters of grapes are three figures. On the grass a gowned nurse (according to the text) with short hair or her hair pulled back stands beside a long-haired boy in a shirt and breeches. She holds a comb poised above his head and gestures toward his hair with her right hand. Behind them a gowned girl(?) sits on the ground in the doorway.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned nurse (according to the text) with short hair or her hair pulled back stands beside a boy. Bending over him from the left and looking down toward him, with her left hand she holds a comb poised above his head as she gestures toward his hair with her right hand, palm vertical. Her feet are visible, and she appears to be wearing shoes.

A male child in breeches and a shirt with a deep V-shaped front opening and white collar stands facing forward, in contrapposto, as his long hair is combed by his nurse. His arms are crossed in front of him at his waist.

Sitting on the ground in the lower right corner of a doorway and facing left is a long-haired female child dressed in a gown. With her head down toward her lap and her left arm bent, she seems to be reading. Though her position is uncertain, her left leg may be doubled under her and her right leg drawn up.

The doorway is framed on either side by leafy grapevines bearing clusters of grapes, one on the left and two on the right. The vines have numerous loops and tendrils, some of which extend beyond the edges of the door frame on both sides. There is grass in the foreground.
The sides, but not the top, of an open doorway in a wall are visible. the blue coloring within the doorway suggests the sky.
The nurse holds a comb.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The grapevine right of the doorway that continues up the right margin of the poem helps to link the main illustration and the interlinear decoration. Besides filling spaces at the ends of short lines (such as 4 and 8), the grapevine that is connected to the main design below separates the two stanzas of the poem with prominent leaves and several loops. There are in addition decorative extensions on letters of the title (line 2), especially the elaborate initial "N" of "NURSES" and the "S" of "Song," whose top is extended rightward into a flower. There are other extensions above letters of the first line (line 3) of the poem and below the "y" in the last line (line 10). A segmented(?) form lying in the decorative extension of the initial "N" of the title suggests a worm, caterpillar, or even a human with head on the right. Blue coloring around the title indicates sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Besides filling spaces at the ends of short lines (such as 4 and 8), the grapevine that is connected to the main design below separates the two stanzas of the poem with prominent leaves and several loops. There are in addition decorative extensions on letters of the title (line 2), especially the elaborate initial "N" of "NURSES" and the "S" of "Song," whose top is extended rightward into a flower. There are other extensions above letters of the first line (line 3) of the poem and below the "y" in the last line (line 10).
A segmented(?) form lying in the decorative extension of the initial "N" of the title (line 2) suggests a worm, caterpillar, or even a swaddled human with head on the right.
Blue coloring around the title indicates sky.

lg.l: When the voices of children. are heard on the greenThe “n” in green printed lightly in this copy and is difficult to see.
And whisprings are in the dale:
The days of my youth rise fresh in my mind,
My face turns green and pale.
Then come home my children. the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Your spring & your day, are wasted in play
And your winter and night in disguise.

desc.objtitle:
The SICK ROSE,
Object 39 (Bentley 39, Erdman 39, Keynes 39)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at bottom left, a rose bush with leaves and prominent thorns surrounds the text. Along the stems that arch over the poem are two gowned females who seem to represent roses that are dying blossoms or blighted buds—in any case, roses whose lives are destroyed by the "dark secret love" of the "invisible worm" (lines 9, 4). One kneels in a severely contracted position while the other lies with her arms wrapped around her lowered head, her gown trailing down along the stem below her. Above them to the left is an S-shaped caterpillar with the lower part of his body on the stem and the upper part resting on a leaf that he may be eating. Below the poem is a globular rose blossom, dense with petals and near its prime. In its opening, to the left, appears the tail end of a worm and, just behind it—perhaps held by it—is a gowned(?) female with her arms raised. The background is washed to suggest the sky. The left and lower right edges of the plate suggest a border of indeterminate vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: Along the stems that arch over the poem are two gowned females who seem to represent roses that are dying blossoms or blighted buds—in any case, roses whose lives are destroyed by the "dark secret love" of the "invisible worm" (lines 9, 4). The one nearer the text kneels, facing right, in a severely contracted position. Her long hair, which falls to the stem, hides her face.

Along the stems that arch over the poem are two gowned females who seem to represent roses that are dying blossoms or blighted buds—in any case, roses whose lives are destroyed by the "dark secret love" of the "invisible worm" (lines 9, 4). The one further from the text lies face down with her arms wrapped around her head, her left leg drawn up and dangling with her foot exposed, and the serpentine tail of her long gown trailing down along the stem below her.
In the opening of a rose blossom, to the left, appears the upper body of a gowned female with her head back, her arms raised at 135 degrees, with hands up, and a worm at her waist.
The tail end of a worm—perhaps a caterpillar if intended as the counterpart of the one at top left—appears in the opening of a rose blossom at the waist of a woman, perhaps holding her.
At upper left is an S-shaped caterpillar—"worm" (line 4) in the context of the poem—with the lower part of his body on the stem and the upper part resting on a leaf that he may be eating.

Rooted at bottom left, a rose bush with appropriately jagged leaves and prominent thorns surrounds the text. Its stems arch over the poem, bend down the right margin, and culminate in a globular blossom, dense with petals and near its prime. Two dying blossoms or blighted buds in the form of gowned women appear on the stems above the text. The left and lower right edges of the plate suggest a border of indeterminate vegetation.
The background is washed to suggest sky. A band of golden tinting, extending diagonally from the top of the second stanza to the end of the title, hints at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: O Rose thou art sick.
The invisible worm.
That flies in the night
In the howling storm:
Has found out thy bed
Of crimson joy:
And his dark secret love.
Does thy life destroy.

desc.objtitle:
THE FLY,
Object 40 (Bentley 40, Erdman 40, Keynes 40)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The handling of barren trees integrates the elements of the plate into a single design. Two trees, both leafless, frame the design. The lower branches of the tree on the right arch over two figures underneath—a female, probably a nurse, dressed in a cap and gown, bending over a small curly-haired male(?) child, also dressed in a gown. The nurse holds the child's raised arms, apparently helping it learn to walk. Behind them to the left stands a long-haired gowned young female hitting a shuttlecock with a badminton racquet. Sky and clouds, colored to suggest sunrise or sunset, are visible above the hill in the background. The nurse and the child on the left seem to be framed by the yellow-tinted cloud(s) behind them. Green wash on the hills suggests grass.

component.illusobjdesc: A female, probably a nurse, completes the arch begun by the trunk and lower branches of a tree to her right, and she is framed by the yellow-tinted cloud behind her. She is dressed in a cap and gown. She bends right over a child and reaches down, holding both its arms, apparently helping it learn to walk. The child also grasps the lower right arm of the nurse with his right hand. Her right(?) foot is visible at the hem of her gown.

A small, curly-haired male(?) child in a gown stands beneath a nurse who leans over him and holds both his arms as if helping him learn to walk. He raises his arms at 135 degrees to reach her lower arms. He steps forward with his right foot.

Facing away from the viewer, but with her face in right profile, a long-haired female child(?) in a gown hits a shuttlecock with a racquet (technically a battledore). With her left arm at her side, her right arm, which holds the racquet, is raised vertically, and she looks up toward the shuttlecock. She strides forward left foot first, right leg extended backward and her right foot visible.

The handling of barren trees integrates the elements of the plate into a single design. Two trees, both leafless, frame the design. The tree on the left forks left of the girl’s raised battledore, and again left of the third stanza. The left branches of these forks extend up the left margin to merge with the border. The right branches also rise up the left margin before arching over the first stanza, under the title. The lower branches of the tree on the right arch over two figures underneath. Its upper branches arch over the title and merge with the top border. Green wash on the hills suggests grass.

Two hills rise in the background to form the horizon. The handling of barren trees integrates the elements of the plate into a single design. Sky and clouds, colored to suggest sunrise or sunset, are visible above the hills in the background. The nurse and the child on the left seem to be framed by the yellow-tinted cloud(s) behind them.
A girl hits a shuttlecock with a racquet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a modest vine-like extension on the initial letter of the title and a more extravagant one on the terminal "y" of line 6. Otherwise interlinear decoration is limited to the bird, fly, or other insect to the right of stanza 5 and to the extensions of the trees on either side: from the left a tendril that grows between the title and the poem and down between the two columns of text; from the right, branches that help ornament the space right of stanza 3, the right margin, and the area right of the title.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a modest vine-like extension on the initial letter of the title and a more extravagant one on the terminal "y" of line 6 and extensions of the trees on either side: from the left a tendril that grows between the title and the poem and down between the two columns of text; from the right, branches that help ornament the space right of stanza 3, the right margin, and the area right of the title.
There is a bird, fly (as in the text), or other flying insect to the right of lines 21-22.

lg.l: Little Fly
Thy summers play,
My thoughtless hand
Has brush'd away.
Am not I
A fly like thee?
Or art not thou
A man like me?
For I dance
And drink & sing:
Till some blind hand
Shall brush my wing.
If thought is life
And strength & breath;
And the want
Of thought is death;
Then am I
A happy fly,
If I live,
Or if I die.

desc.objtitle:
The Angel,
Object 41 (Bentley 41, Erdman 41, Keynes 41)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the grass under the arching branches of a tree with a large trunk rooted at left are two forward-facing figures. The "maiden Queen" (line 4) of the poem reclines, resting her head on her right hand as she reaches up and back with her left, pushing (perhaps also holding) the face of the male "Angel mild" (line 5), apparently fending off his advances ("I was arm'd, he came in vain," line 16). His right arm lies along her left as his left hand reaches across his body to touch her left arm. He is nude, with the suggestion of genitals, and has short hair, and large wings; she is gowned, has long hair, and is crowned. From the tree above, the loops of a leafless vine rise between the two figures. There is a hedge or hill behind them. The sky is blue with a rosy tint on the left, behind the tree, suggesting sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The "maiden Queen" (line 4) of the poem reclines on her right side, resting her head on her right hand as she reaches up and back with her raised left arm to push away (perhaps hold) the face of the male "Angel mild" (line 5), apparently fending off his advances ("I was arm'd, he came in vain," line 16). Her posture suggests melancholy. She is gowned, has long hair, and is crowned. She may be wearing a belt. With her head at the left at the base of the tree, she faces forward and looks out toward the left—away from the Angel. Her left foot is visible and her mouth is slightly open as though she is speaking.

The "maiden Queen" (line 4) of the poem apparently fends off the advances of a cupid-like "Angel mild" (line 5) ("I was arm'd, he came in vain," line 16). The angel stands behind her so that his contrapposto stance is visible only from the thighs up. He faces forward and looks diagonally down toward the maiden. His right arm lies along her left as his left hand reaches across his body to touch her left arm. He is nude, with the suggestion of genitals, and has short hair and large wings.

On the grass under the arching branches of a tree with a large trunk rooted at left are two forward-facing figures. From the tree above, the loops of a leafless vine spiral upward between the two figures. There is a hedge or hill behind them. The woman rests upon a strip of grassy ground.
A strip of grassy ground runs along the bottom margin. This strip and the grassy strip upon which the woman rests frame the text area.
The sky is blue with a rosy tint on the left, behind the tree, suggesting sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine growing from the initial letter of the title dangles down the left margin; another extends across the bottom and up around the last stanza with a loopy flourish; a third, serpentine and loopy, extends into the right margin from the "y" of "day" (line 7) and has a leaf; and a fourth, with spiky leaves (perhaps ivy) fills space to the right of the title. Some other letters also have vine- or leaf-like extensions, particularly the "y" of "grey" and the "y" of "my" in line 18.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine growing from the initial letter of the title dangles down the left margin; another extends across the bottom and up around the last stanza with a loopy flourish; a third, serpentine and loopy, extends into the right margin from the "y" of "day" (line 7) and has a grape(?) leaf; and a fourth, with spiky leaves (perhaps ivy) fills space to the right of the title. Some other letters also have vine- or leaf-like extensions, particularly the "y" of "grey" and the "y" of "my" in line 18.

lg.l: I Dreamt a Dream! what can it mean?
And that I was a maiden Queen:
Guarded by an Angel mild:
Witless woe, was ne'er beguil'd!
And I wept both night and day
And he wip'd my tears away
And I wept both day and night
And hid from him my hearts delight
So he took his wings and fled;
Then the morn blush'd rosy red;
I dried my tears & arm'd my fears,
With ten thousand shields and spears
Soon my Angel came again;
I was arm'd, he came in vain;
For the time of youth was fled
And grey hairs were on my head

desc.objtitle:
The Tyger The Tiger,
Object 42 (Bentley 42, Erdman 42, Keynes 42)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the grass under barren limbs of the tree in the right margin stands a tiger facing left, perhaps walking. The cat has a prominent open eye and stripes of black are visible on its orange body. Vine-like tendrils, apparently extensions of a tuft of grass-like vegetation at lower left, occupy the left margin. The tyger casts a shadow on the ground, but the blue sky in the background gives no clear indication that this is a "night" (line 4) scene.

component.illusobjdesc: A left-facing tiger, with a prominent open eye and stripes of black on its orange body, stands or perhaps walks on the grass beneath a barren tree. The cat's left rear leg is extended backward; the dark area on his back may be a shadow.

A tiger stands on the grass under the barren limbs of a tree with a wide base in the right margin. Shadows(?) stripe the right side of this tree, forming a visual parallel with the tiger’s stripes. Vine-like tendrils—without loops, leaves, or fruit—apparently extend from a tuft of a grass-like plant at lower left and occupy the left margin. Other mounds of indeterminate vegetation appear right and left of the tiger's forelegs. Though "forests of the night" (line 4) are mentioned in the text, only the one tree is pictured.
A shadow, probably cast by the tiger, extends across the grassy ground upon which the tiger stands.
Blue coloring behind the tiger and in the text area indicate sky, but there is no clear indication that this is a "night" (line 4) scene.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The barren limbs of the tree in the right margin fork around the right end of the title and mark divisions between the title and stanza 1, stanzas 1 and 2, stanzas 3 and 4 (there joining the straight vine-like tendrils on the left), and stanzas 5 and 6. There is a single loop in the extension from the initial "T" of the title (line 2). Two tendrils rise from the tuft at bottom left, extending up the left margin. There is a decorative extension on the "y" in the title and on three uses of the letter "y" in the final line of the poem (line 26). A bird flies above "Tyger Tyger" in line 3.

component.illusobjdesc: The barren limbs of the tree in the right margin fork around the right end of the title and mark divisions between the title and stanza 1, stanzas 1 and 2, stanzas 3 and 4 (there joining the straight vine-like tendrils of vegetation on the left), and stanzas 5 and 6. There is a single loop in the extension from the initial "T" of the title (line 2). Two tendrils rise from the tuft at bottom left, extending up the left margin. There is a decorative extension on the "y" in the title and on three "y's" in the final line of the poem (line 26).
A bird flies above "Tyger Tyger" in line 3.

lg.l: Tyger Tyger. burning bright,
In the forests of the night;
What immortal hand or eye,
Could frame thy fearful symmetry?
In what distant deeps or skies.
Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
On what wings dare he aspire?
What the hand, dare sieze the fire?
And what shoulder, & what art,
Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
And when thy heart began to beat.
What dread hand? & what dread feet?
What the hammer? what the chain,
In what furnace was thy brain?
What the anvil? what dread grasp,
Dare its deadly terrors clasp!
When the stars threw down their spears
And water'd heaven with their tears:
Did he smile his work to see?
Did he who made the Lamb make thee?
Tyger Tyger burning bright,
In the forests of the night;
What immortal hand or eye,
Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?

desc.objtitle:
My Pretty ROSE TREE,
Object 43 (Bentley 43, Erdman 43, Keynes 43)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Of the three poems on the plate, only "My Pretty ROSE TREE" (line 2), at the top, has anything other than interlinear and marginal designs. Beneath its text, beside a tree with leafless branches that occupies the right margin, are two figures. At the base of the tree a gowned female with long hair reclines, the weight of her upper body apparently supported by her bent left arm. She may be the pretty rose tree of the poem. At her feet, facing right beside a plant or tuft of grass, is a second gowned figure, sitting (or perhaps kneeling) in a contracted position. This may be the male who "tend[s]" the rose-tree "by day and by night" (line 8). His right upper arm and left lower arm and hand are visible, and he seems to have his left hand tucked between his head and shoulder. Pale rose and blue wash in the area behind the figures and text, growing darker toward the top left, suggests a cloudy sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. A flock of nine birds flies above the reclining female alongside one larger bird, soaring upward with outstretched wings, right of the male’s head.

component.illusobjdesc: At the base of the tree a gowned female with long hair reclines, the weight of her upper body apparently supported by her bent left arm. Her head may be resting on her left hand; her right arm is bent across her chest. She may be the pretty rose tree of the poem. Her posture suggests melancholy.

At the feet of the reclining female, facing right in front of a tuft of grass, is a second gowned figure, sitting (or perhaps kneeling) in a contracted position. This may be the male who "tend[s]" the rose-tree "by day and by night" (line 8). His right upper arm and left lower arm and hand are visible, and he seems to have his left hand tucked between his head and shoulder.
A flock of nine birds flies above the reclining female alongside one larger bird, soaring upward with outstretched wings, right of the male’s head.

A tree with an oddly shaped trunk, a spreading base, and two leafless branches occupies the right margin of the upper panel. A vine with four leaves grows at its base. Some indeterminate vegetation—perhaps a plant or tufted grass of some sort—grows left of the figure on the left.
Pale rose and blue wash in the area behind the figures and text, growing darker toward the top left, suggests a cloudy sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the top panel a leafless branch of the right-hand tree helps, with three flying birds, to separate title (line 2) from text. There are three very loopy vine-like letter extensions, two in the title, from the initial "M" and the "T" of "TREE," and a third, in the left margin, from the initial letter of line 10. There are other decorative extensions on the initial letters of lines 3-4.

component.illusobjdesc: Three flying birds, one larger and two smaller, help separate title from text.

In the top panel a leafless branch of the right-hand tree helps, with three flying birds, to separate title from text. There are three very loopy but leafless vine-like letter extensions, two in the title (line 2), from the initial "M" and the "T" of "TREE," and a third, in the left margin, from the initial letter of line 10. There are other decorative extensions on the initial letters of lines 3-4.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the middle panel, left of the title (line 11), a gowned female(?) leaps, facing right; her arms are bent upward, possibly with hands together as though praying. Her gown is extended in vine-like loops down the left margin. She may be the anthropomorphic form of the sunflower in the text. The final letter of the title is extended up and back in a serpentine vine-like line across the top of the title. Above the word "LILLY" (line 20) in the lower panel, the line that separates the middle from the bottom panel sprouts a loopy vine-like extension upward into the right margin beside the second stanza of "AH! SUN-FLOWER" (line 11). The printed area right of the first stanza of "AH! SUN-FLOWER" suggests a cloudy sky. The disc of the sun, prominent in other copies, is colored like the adjacent clouds in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: In the middle panel, left of the title (line 11), a female(?) leaps, facing right; her arms appear are bent upward, possibly with hands together as though praying. She may be wearing a gown; at least some drapery seems to be trailing from her. Her gown is extended in vine-like loops, suggestive of a spiral, down the left margin. She may be the anthropomorphic form of the personified sunflower of the text. Her hair is long and streams out behind her to the left.

The final letter of the title (line 11) in the middle panel is extended in a serpentine vine-like line across the top of the title. Above the word "LILLY" (line 20) in lower panel, the line that separates the middle from the bottom panel sprouts a loopy vine-like extension upward into the right margin beside the second stanza of "AH! SUN-FLOWER."
The printed area right of the first stanza of "AH! SUN-FLOWER" suggests a cloudy sky. The disc of the sun, prominent in other copies, is colored like the adjacent clouds in this copy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the lower panel, the initial letter of the title (line 20) is highly ornamented with a loopy vine-like extension to the left. Just below it begins another vine-like ornament that surrounds the text on the left and bottom, ending with a loop and stroke left of the final word of the poem, which is set off in the position usually reserved for catchwords. Right of the title is a lily plant that bends down into the right margin and terminates in a flower.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower panel, the initial letter of the title is highly ornamented with a loopy but leafless vine-like extension to the left. A detached(?) leaf or vine appears above the loopy vine. Just below it begins another vine-like ornament that surrounds the text on the left and bottom, ending with a loop and stroke left of the final word of the poem, which is set off in the position usually reserved for catchwords. The upper end of this vine, just above "modest" in line 21, bears a leaf. Right of the title is a lily plant that bends down into the right margin and terminates in a flower.

lg.l: A flower was offerd to me;
Such a flower as May never bore.
But I said I've a Pretty Rose-tree.
And I passed the sweet flower o'er.
Then I went to my Pretty Rose-tree;
To tend her by day and by night.
But my Rose turnd away with jealousy:
And her thorns were my only delight.
Ah Sun-flower! weary of time,
Who countest the steps of the Sun:
Seeking after that sweet golden clime.
Where the travellers journey is done.
Where the Youth pined away with desire,
And the pale Virgin shrouded in snow:
Arise from their graves and aspire,
Where my Sun-flower wishes to go.
The modest Rose puts forth a thorn:
The humble Sheep, a threatning horn;
While the Lilly white, shall in Love delight,
Nor a thorn nor a threat stain her beauty
bright

desc.objtitle:
The GARDEN of LOVE,
Object 44 (Bentley 44, Erdman 44, Keynes 44)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three figures kneel, facing right, on the ground before an open grave. The two gowned children(?) on the left, probably male (left) and female (right), pray while the tonsured, gowned priest on the right looks toward a book in one hand as he gestures with the other toward the grave. Behind the priest’s head is a golden halo. A tombstone with ornate scrolled top stands before them at far right. Behind and above them is what looks like an area of dark sky, or perhaps vegetation, with either a patch of sunlight or light cast by the halo just above the priest's head. There is a window with diamond-shaped panes just above the tombstone, with a vine or branch growing beside it. The window may be part of a church or the "Chapel . . . on the green" (lines 5-6). On the left is a tree with a bare branch that extends over the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing right, a short-haired male (left) and long-haired female (right), both gowned, kneel in prayer beside a priest before an open grave. Their heads are down, their arms are bent upward, and their hands are clasped together, probably in prayer.

Facing right in a dark gown with cowl or hooded collar, a priest kneels beside a boy and girl before an open grave. As they pray, he reads from an open book that he holds in his right hand, as if leading them in prayer. With his left hand he gestures downward toward the grave. His palm is out, fingers spread. Behind his head is a golden halo.
The priest holds an open book in his right hand.

To the left of the kneeling figures, a tree stands in the margin, with a bare branch extending over the figures. Other vegetation may be indicated by the coloring and lines behind them. A vine or branch grows just left of the background window. There is the suggestion of grass on the ground beneath the figure on the left.
Behind and above the kneeling figures is what looks like an area of dark sky, with either a patch of sunlight or light cast by the halo just above the priest's head.
On the ground in front of the kneeling figures is an open grave, suggesting (in terms of the text) that the garden of love has become a graveyard.
Right of the priest is a tombstone with an ornate scrolled top.
Above the tombstone, a window with diamond-shaped panes may be part of a church or the "Chapel . . . on the green" (lines 5-6).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Across the bottom of the plate stretches a grave bound in (customary) crisscrossed briars.

component.illusobjdesc: Across the bottom of the plate stretches a grave.
A grave is bound in (customary) crisscrossed briars.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Serpentine shapes—worms or leafless vines with only slight suggestions of greenery—dominate the interlinear spaces in the right margin and between stanzas. Smaller vines or vermicular forms appear above and to the left of line 3. The initial letters of the first two words and the final letter of the third word of the title are lightly ornamented with similar loopy extensions (line 2). Below the text at lower right are two small branches with leaves on them. These might be extensions of the briars below.

component.illusobjdesc: Serpentine shapes—worms or leafless vines with only slight suggestions of greenery—dominate the interlinear spaces in the right margin and between stanzas. Smaller vines or vermicular forms appear above and to the left of line 3. The particularly loopy form right of stanzas 1 and 2 suggests it is very likely a worm, as befits the imagery of graves in both text and designs. The initial letters of the first two words and the final letter of the third word of the title (line 2) are lightly ornamented with vine-like extensions. Below the text at lower right are two small branches with the outlines of leaves on them. These might be extensions of the briars below.
Pale blue washes in the text area suggest sky in the background.

lg.l: I went to the Garden of Love.
And saw what I never had seen:
A Chapel was built in the midst,
Where I used to play on the green.
And the gates of this Chapel were shut,
And Thou shalt not. writ over the door;
So I turn'd to the Garden of Love,
That so many sweet flowers bore.
And I saw it was filled with graves,
And tomb-stones where flowers should be:
And Priests in black gowns, were walking their
rounds,
And binding with briars, my joys & desires.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Vagabond,
Object 45 (Bentley 45, Erdman 45, Keynes 45)

objnote.p: Almost all the text was over-written in pen and black ink.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures huddle together among the trunks of trees. A gowned old man, with long hair and beard, kneels facing right. He may represent "God like a father" mentioned in the text (line 15). His back, head, and extended left arm form a protective arch into which nestles the tightly contracted and arched nude body of a young male(?), whose bent left arm extends upward along the right arm of the old man. The area around them is lit by the beams from the old man's bright halo. There may be some dark foliage in the background above the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man, with long hair, beard, and bright halo, kneels facing right. His back, head, and extended left arm and forefinger form a protective arch into which nestles a nude young male. The upper body of the young man is held and supported by the old man's right arm and hand, which appears under the young man's chest. He may represent "God like a father" mentioned in the text (line 15). The halo emits spiky beams of light.

Facing left, the tightly contracted and arched nude body of a young male(?) nestles into the arched body of a bearded old man, as if seeking protection. The youth's bent left arm extends upward along the old man's right arm.
Two figures huddle together in a kind of forest cavern formed by the large trunks of trees. There may be some dark foliage in the background above the figures.
The old man's bright halo sheds beams of light that echo the fire in the illustration at the bottom of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On an area of grass, several figures with indistinct features surround a blazing fire in the center: left of the fire, facing right, a male in tights kneels with his head on his hand; a child(?) stands in the background between him and the fire; on the ground to the right of the fire, a gowned female(?), facing forward, sits on the ground with her legs drawn up and crossed; directly in front of her kneels a nude child with its right arm about her neck and the left arm on her prominent right knee; beside her stands another child, also apparently nude. The left(?) arm of the child farthest right is bent upward to touch the woman. Together the group of figures suggests a family of father, mother, and children. Plants or bushes grow right and left of the group of figures. The background area surrounding the figures’ heads is colored to suggest the sky, and there are four birds flying in the lower right margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Together the group of figures suggests a family of father, mother, and three children.

Left of the fire, on a mound of some sort, a short-haired male in tights kneels facing right with his left leg extended. His left arm is bent to support his head, which rests on his left hand; his right arm is at his side. His posture suggests melancholy. He may represent the father in the family group that seems to be depicted.
Between the fire and the kneeling male to the left of it is an indistinct figure, probably a child, standing in the background and probably facing right.

Sitting on the ground to the right of the fire is a gowned female(?) figure. She faces forward with her legs drawn up and crossed in front of her. Though indistinct, her head seems to be down. She may be the mother of the children depicted. Her contracted posture with prominent knees suggests despair.
Close beside the sitting female stands a nude child. Facing left and away, the child appears to reach out for its mother(?) with its raised and bent left(?) arm.

With body twisted and facing away from the viewer, a nude child kneels directly in front of the kneeling female and reaches up, embracing her head or neck with the right arm and holding her prominent right knee with the left arm.
The family group surrounds a blazing fire.
In the sky above the right group of figures below are four flying birds. One of them has outspread wings and a forked tail.
A grassy area stretches across the bottom of the plate, with a mound of some sort apparent beneath the figure on the left. Plants or bushes grow right and left of the group of figures.
The background area surrounding the figures’ heads is colored to suggest a sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There are vine-like decorative flourishes off some letters of the title and into the space above and below the title. From the terminal "d" of the title (line 2) a loopy vine—with three grape leaves right of the first stanza—runs well down the right margin beside the first three stanzas. Down the left margin, the initial letters of the lines are slightly embellished, as are a few letters here and there throughout the poem. Other features of the area in and around the text, such as the birds, are extensions of the illustration below the text.

component.illusobjdesc: There are vine-like decorative flourishes off some letters of the title and into the space above and below the title. From the terminal "d" of the title (line 2) a loopy vine—with three grape leaves right of the first stanza—runs well down the right margin beside the first three stanzas. Down the left margin, the initial letters of the lines are slightly embellished, as are a few letters here and there throughout the poem.

lg.l: Dear Mother, dear Mother, the Church is cold,
But the Ale-house is healthy & pleasant & warm;
Besides I can tell where I am use'd well,
Such usage in heaven will never do well,
But if at the Church they would give us some Ale.
And a pleasant fire, our souls to regale;
We'd sing and we'd pray all the live-long day:
Nor ever once wish from the Church to stray,
Then the Parson might preach & drink & sing,
And we'd be as happy as birds in the spring:
And modest dame Lurch. who is always at Church.
Would not have bandy children nor fasting nor birch.
And God like a father rejoicing to see,
His children as pleasant and happy as he:
Would have no more quarrel with the Devil or the BarrelThe "l" of "Barrel" was not etched on the plate. In this copy, the letter was added in pen and black ink.
But kiss him & give him both drink and apparel.

desc.objtitle:
LONDON,
Object 46 (Bentley 46, Erdman 46, Keynes 46)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with long hair and a very long beard walks right with the aid of crutches. In front of him, a gowned, curly-haired male child may be leading him. The child, looking back at the old man, reaches up toward him with his right hand and holds his left hand out and down, as if showing the way. The location, judging from the poem, is a London street. Cobblestones, of which the street is perhaps composed, are visible right of the child’s feet; they descend into the text area to the right of the title. The man and child stand in a shaft of light that cuts diagonally across the stone wall and wooden doorway behind them.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with long hair and a very long beard walks right with the aid of crutches. His right leg is extended backward. He may be looking down toward the boy or the ground, or his eyes may be closed, or he may be blind.

A gowned, curly-haired male child may be leading an old man. With his right foot forward, the child turns to look up and back at the old man, reaching up toward him with his right hand and holding his left hand out and down, as if showing the way.

Behind the figures is a stone wall, probably of a building, penetrated right of center by a large (probably wooden) door. Judging from the poem, the scene is a London street; its cobblestones are indicated by the round shapes right of the child’s feet, which descend into the text area right of the title.
The figures walk in a shaft of light that cuts diagonally across the wall and door behind them, thereby creating diagonal shadows upper right and lower left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Kneeling, a short-haired child, nude or wearing tights, reaches out to warm his/her hands at a blazing fire that sends billows of dark smoke into the area above.

component.illusobjdesc: Kneeling and facing left, a short-haired child, nude or wearing tights, reaches out to warm his/her hands, palms out, at a blazing fire.
A blazing fire sends out billows of smoke that spread out over the entire lower right area of the plate to serve as background for the text, though the coloring may also indicate a cloudy sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Interlinear ornamentation is sparse. There are vine- or leaf-like extensions on a few letters of the text, such as the "h" of "thro" (line 3). The serpentine extension on the initial letter of the title runs down the entire left margin. A particularly serpentine form, possibly a snake with its head on the right, undulates just above the narrow strip of earth along the lower border. The horizontal marks right of the last stanza, below the boy, resist specific identification. There is a strong horizontal line between the title and first stanza, and there are two much smaller lines between the second and third stanzas. Another horizontal line, perhaps the fire’s shadow, separates the third and fourth stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: There are vine-like or leaf-like extensions on a few letters of the text, such as the "h" of "thro" (line 3). The serpentine extension on the initial letter of the title runs down the entire left margin. A particularly serpentine form, possibly a snake with its head on the right, undulates just above the narrow strip of earth along the lower border. There is a strong horizontal line between the title and first stanza, and there are two much smaller lines between the second and third stanzas. Another horizontal line, perhaps the fire’s shadow, separates the third and fourth stanzas.
The serpentine form undulating just above the lower border may be a snake with its head on the right.

lg.l: I wander thro' each charter'd street,
Near where the charter'd Thames does flow
And mark in every face I meet
Marks of weakness. marks of woe,
In every cry of every Man,
In every Infants cry of fear.
In every voice; in every ban.
The mind-forg'd manacles I hear
How the Chimney-sweepers cry
Every blacknng Church appalls."blacknng": i.e., presumably, "black'ning".
And the hapless Soldiers sigh
Runs in blood down Palace walls
But most thro' midnight streets I hear
How the youthful Harlots curse
Blasts the new born Infants tear
And blights with plagues the Marriage hearse

desc.objtitle:
The Human Abstract,
Object 47 (Bentley 47, Erdman 47, Keynes 47)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with a long beard kneels, facing the viewer, with his legs outspread. He appears to struggle under ropes—or perhaps parts of a net. His arms are raised over his head where he grips the ropes, as if attempting to free himself. His body, the ropes, and the ground beneath outline a triangle. Beneath the grassy ground are horizontal lines and blue wash that probably indicate a river or other body of water. Left of the old man, arching fronds of indeterminate vegetation, possibly reeds or cattails, appear in the background. A tree with a narrow base extends up the left margin. A tree trunk with a broad base extends up the right margin; a few of its leafless branches (or perhaps a leafless vine) fill marginal spaces, and its long branch reaches across the top margin. Together, the trees at left and right, the branch at top, and the river at bottom frame the entire plate. There is a small portion of dark blue sky visible behind and just above the old man, and there is lighter, possibly cloudy sky behind the text area.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with a long beard kneels, facing the viewer, with his legs outspread. He appears to struggle under ropes—or perhaps parts of a net. His arms are raised over his head where he grips the ropes, as if attempting to free himself. His body, the ropes, and the ground beneath outline a triangle.

Arching fronds of indeterminate vegetation, possibly reeds or cattails, appear in the background to the left of the old man. A tree with a narrow base extends up the left margin. A tree trunk with a broad base extends up the right margin; a few of its leafless branches—or perhaps a separate vine—fill marginal spaces, and its long branch reaches across the top margin. Together, the trees at left and right, the branch at top, and the river at bottom frame the entire plate. The ground below may be grassy.
Beneath the strip of grassy ground near the bottom margin are horizontal lines and blue wash that probably indicate a river or other body of water.
A small portion of dark blue sky, possibly filled with clouds, is visible behind and just above the old man, and there is lighter, possibly cloudy sky behind the text area.

An old man appears to struggle under ropes—or perhaps parts of a net. His arms are raised over his head where he grips the ropes, as if attempting to free himself. His body, the ropes—two to the left, two to the right—and the ground beneath outline a triangle.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Except for the flourish of vine-like ornamentation on the initial letter of the title and the leafless branches of the tree on the right (which might be regarded as elements of the main design), the plate is without interlinear decoration.

component.illusobjdesc: The initial letter of the title is ornamented with a vine-like extension with a single loop.

lg.l: Pity would be no more,
If we did not make somebody Poor:
And Mercy no more could be.
If all were as happy as we;
And mutual fear brings peace;
Till the selfish loves increase.
Then Cruelty knits a snare,
And spreads his baits with care.
He sits down with holy fears,
And waters the ground with tears:
Then Humility takes its root
Underneath his foot.
Soon spreads the dismal shade
Of Mystery over his head;
And the Catterpiller and Fly,
Feed on the Mystery.
And it bears the fruit of Deceit.
Ruddy and sweet to eat;
And the Raven his nest has made
In its thickest shade.
The Gods of the earth and sea,
Sought thro' Nature to find this Tree
But their search was all in vain:
There grows one in the Human Brain

desc.objtitle:
INFANT SORROW,
Object 48 (Bentley 48, Erdman 48, Keynes 48)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female with a cap bends forward as she reaches with outstretched arms for a nude infant with its head and arms raised and its right leg bent back at the knee. They are presumably the mother and infant of the text (title, line 10). The infant sits with its back against a pillow on a small bed with a wicker base. Behind them is a larger curtained bed with pillow and sheet. On the floor is mottled carpeting.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing away from the viewer and to the right, a nude infant with short and curly(?) hair—very probably male and presumably the unhappy infant of the title—sits with its head up, its arms raised between the vertical and 135 degrees, and its right leg bent back at the knee. It sits on a bed with its back against a pillow. Its hands are raised, palms out and with fingers slightly spread.
Facing left, a gowned female wearing a cap—presumably the mother of the text (line 10)—bends forward as she reaches, arms outstretched and visible palm up, for an infant.

The background is occupied by a curtained adult bed. The mattress, covered by what may be a blanket or other covering, lies on a draped platform; there is also a pillow behind the mother. Closed curtains hang on the far side of the bed, open curtains on the near side. The curtains to the right extend up the margin beside the text; the curtains to the left seem to hang partially from a point just beneath the last line of text (line 10).
The infant sits against a pillow on a small bed with a wicker base. The bed is covered by a sheet.
The floor is covered by a mottled carpet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Between the title and the opening line of the poem, a line extends horizontally from the curtain on the right to a point over the first word. A second line, possibly suggesting a fold in the curtains, extends vertically from left of the title to the beginning of stanza 2.

component.illusobjdesc: Between the title (line 2) and the opening line of the poem (line 3), a line extends horizontally from the curtain on the right to a point over the first word (line 3). A second line, probably suggesting a fold in the curtains, extends vertically from left of the title to the beginning of stanza 2 (line 6).

lg.l: My mother groand! my father wept.
Into the dangerous world I leapt:
Helpless, naked, piping loud:
Like a fiend hid in a cloud.
Struggling in my fathers hands:
Striving against my swadling bands:
Bound and weary I thought best
To sulk upon my mothers breast.

desc.objtitle:
A POISON TREE,
Object 49 (Bentley 49, Erdman 49, Keynes 49)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dark setting, beneath two arching branches from the tree on the right, lies a long-haired male, supine and probably nude, with the top of his head toward the viewer. He is presumably the (dead?) "foe outstretchd beneath the tree" (line 18)—the poison tree of the title. His arms are outstretched along the ground in cruciform position. two lines over his torso suggest that he is bound with ropes. The tree extends the length of the right margin, sending forth several narrow branches, the longest reaching between the title and the first line of the poem (line 3). An area of cloudy sky, colored to suggest sunrise or sunset, is visible above the figure and behind the text area. The figure lies on flat, grassy ground, and a hill or mountain appears along the horizon.

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired, probably nude male lies supine, with the top of his head toward the viewer, his body arranged at a slight angle to the right. He is presumably the (dead?) "foe outstretchd beneath the tree" (line 18)—the poison tree of the title. His arms are outstretched along the ground in cruciform position. Two lines over his torso suggest that he is bound with ropes.

The poison tree of the title—an apple tree according to the text—extends the length of the right margin, sending out several narrow branches, the longest of which extends between the title and the first line of the poem (line3). Two large leafless(?) branches also arch over the figure lying on the ground. A few small branches extend into the spaces of the right margin and between stanzas, most notably the branch between the title and the first stanza, which forks upward at the left end of the title and downward (resembling, perhaps, a vine more than a branch) along the left margin until it joins the "y" of "My" (line 18). The curved form right of line 15 may be another branch of the tree, although not attached to it.
An area of cloudy sky, colored to suggest sunrise or sunset, is visible above the supine figure and behind the text area. A patch of dark blue sky fills the top left corner.
The supine figure lies on flat, grassy ground, and a hill or mountain appears along the horizon.

lg.l: I was angry with my friend;
I told my wrath, my wrath did end.
I was angry with my foe:
I told it not. my wrath did grow.
And I waterd it in fears,
Night & morning with my tears:
And I sunned it with smiles,
And with soft deceitful wiles.
And it grew both day and night,
Till it bore an apple bright.
And my foe beheld it shine,
And he knew that it was mine.
And into my garden stole,
When the night had veild the pole:
In the morning glad I see;
My foe outstretchd beneath the tree.

desc.objtitle:
A Little BOY Lost,
Object 50 (Bentley 50, Erdman 50, Keynes 50)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On a strip of stony(?) ground, two gowned figures with long hair, or with their heads covered by their gowns, kneel facing a fire to the left—presumably the fire in which the little boy of the title (line 2) is sacrificed. They hold their heads down and their hands to their faces. Behind them to the right are at least 4, possibly 5, other kneeling figures, the most prominent also probably gowned. At far right stands a gowned figure of indeterminate sex with indistinct features, its arms raised to clasp its head. The postures of all the figures suggest despair or grief. Dark blue wash that suggests night sky appears directly above and in front of the two central figures. Within the text area are streaks of yellow wash that may suggest a cloudy sky, a suggestion corroborated by light and dark blue wash in the top left corner. Ivy fills the right margin and extends over the title, while a flame and smoke rise up the left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Two gowned figures with long hair, or with their heads covered by their gowns, kneel facing a fire to the left—presumably the fire in which the little boy of the title is sacrificed. They hold their heads down and their hands to their faces. Behind them to the right are four, possibly five, other kneeling figure, the most prominent also gowned. The face of none of the kneeling figures is visible. The postures of all the figures suggest despair or grief.
At far right stands a gowned figure of indeterminate sex and with indistinct features, its arms raised to clasp its head.
The two central gowned figures kneel on what may be a strip of bare or stony(?) ground.

Dark blue wash that suggests night sky appears directly above and in front of the two central figures. Within the text area (and distinct from the coloring above the figures) are streaks of yellow wash that may suggest a cloudy sky, a suggestion corroborated by light and dark blue wash in the top left corner.

Spiky three-cornered leaves, perhaps of ivy, extend up the right margin from just above the figure at lower right and connect to the terminal letter of the title, where it forks into a tendril that extends over "Lost" and part of "BOY" of the title (line 2).
A fire, probably the one in which the little boy of the title is sacrificed, burns at lower left and sends a column of flame and smoke up the left margin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The right marginal spaces are occupied by a leafy ivy vine that connects with the terminal letter of the title and extends over "Lost" and part of "BOY" in the title (line 2). But that element seems well integrated into the full-plate design. The only other interlinear elements are occasional vine-like extensions of letters of the text, such as the extravagant forked extension between the first and second stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: The only interlinear elements that are not integrated into the full-plate design are various vine-like extensions of letters of the text, such as those from the initial letter of the title, the "h" near the middle of line 3, the "h" near the middle of line 7 that forks into a line between the first and second stanzas, and the "A" of "Albions" in the last line (line 26).

lg.l: Nought loves another as itself
Nor venerates another so.
Nor is it possible to thought
A greater than itself to know:
And Father, how can I love you,
Or any of my brothers more?
I love you like the little bird
That picks up crumbs around the door.
The Priest sat by and heard the child.
In trembling zeal he siez'd his hair:
He led him by his little coat:
And all admir'd the Priestly care.
And standing on the altar high,
Lo what a fiend is here! said he:
One who sets reason up for judge
Of our most holy Mystery.
The weeping child could not be heard.
The weeping parents wept in vain:
They strip'd him to his little shirt.
And bound him in an iron chain.
And burn'd him in a holy place,
Where many had been burn'd before:
The weeping parents wept in vain.
Are such things done on Albions shore.

desc.objtitle:
A Little GIRL Lost,
Object 51 (Bentley 51, Erdman 51, Keynes 51)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A barren tree rooted at lower right occupies most of the right margin. A grapevine(?) with a few leaves climbs the tree trunk and sends out long, loopy tendrils.
