A small human figure stands on the top curve of the vine. Right of the fifth stanza, a squirrel with a bushy tail appears in a crook of the tree; it may be climbing upward. A second, narrower tree(?) grows in the left margin and, at top left, merges with the plate’s border. Many birds fly around and in between the text. Yellow, blue, and purple washes with white streaks behind the text area suggest a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In the top curve of the vine, right of lines 11-13, stands a small left-facing figure with its arms raised at 135 degrees to hold onto the vine. The figure may be walking to the left.

Right of the fifth stanza, a squirrel with a bushy tail appears in a crook of the tree. It faces right but looks upward, stands on its hind legs, and leans with its front legs against the trunk. Its pose suggests that it may be climbing upward.

There are many flying birds in the sky. The most prominent are the two with outspread wings and forked tails below the first word of the title and another beneath the last word of the title (line 2), but there are at least 19 others.
A barren tree rooted at lower right occupies most of the right margin. A second, narrower tree(?) grows in the left margin and, at top left, merges with the plate’s border.

A grapevine(?) with a few leaves—three prominent ones opposite the third stanza, two that resemble grape leaves and one oddly elongated—climbs the tree trunk and sends out long, loopy tendrils into the spaces of the right margin: the one at the bottom curves back on itself and ends just above the "h" of "hoary" in the last line (line 36). The topmost one curls around a limb just above a small human figure near the top of the tree.
Yellow, blue, and purple washes with white streaks behind the text area suggest a cloudy sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There are few interlinear elements. The initial "C" of line 3 has a fancy vine-like extension that loops above the title and is attached to the "G" in the title (line 2), and a bold horizontal line underscores the third and fourth words of the title. A few other words, notably "weary" in the last line of stanza 5 (line 26), have decorative extensions. A flock of birds also divides stanzas 6 and 7.

component.illusobjdesc: The initial "C" of line 3 has a fancy vine-like extension that loops above the title and is attached to the "G" in the title (line 2). A few other words, notably "weary" in the last line of stanza 5 (line 26), have decorative extensions.
A bold horizontal line underscores the third and fourth words of the title.
A flock of birds divides stanzas 6 and 7.

lg.l: Children of the future Age,
Reading this indignant page;
Know that in a former time,
Love! sweet Love! was thought a crime.
In the Age of Gold,
Free from winters cold:
Youth and maiden bright,
To the holy light,
Naked in the sunny beams delight.
Once a youthful pair
Fill'd with softest care;
Met in garden bright.
Where the holy light,
Had just removd the curtains of the night.
There in rising day,
On the grass they play:
Parents were afar;
Strangers came not near:
And the maiden soon forgot her fear.
Tired with kisses sweet
They agree to meet,
When the silent sleep
Waves o'er heavens deep;
And the weary tired wanderers weep.The “we” in “weary” printed very lightly and is difficult to see in this copy.
To her father white
Came the maiden bright:
But his loving look.
Like the holy book,
All her tender limbs with terror shook.
Ona! pale and weak!
To thy father speak:
O the trembling fear!
O the dismal care!hair
That shakes the blossoms of my hoary

desc.objtitle:
To Tirzah,
Object 52 (Bentley 52, Erdman 52, Keynes 52)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the base of a grassy mound or hill stand two gowned women who bend over a long-haired(?) nude male—who may be dead—as if attempting to raise him from a supine to a sitting position. His head is up and the visible portions of his legs are crossed. To the right, facing them, a bearded and gowned old man, holding a pitcher, bends over the male on the ground. Etched vertically on the old man's gown is "It is Raised a Spiritual Body" (derived from 1 Corinthians 15:44). The arrangement of the three standing figures creates an implied arch, and above the group arches the branch of a fruit-bearing tree—perhaps apple—with six or seven round fruits and several leaves. The tree trunk extends upward along the right margin. The area above the lower design is colored to suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing right, two gowned women bend over a nude male, reaching down to hold him by the chest and shoulders as if attempting to raise him from a supine into a sitting position. The hair of the woman at far left is pulled back; the hair of the other woman hangs down her left arm.

Two women seem to be attempting to raise a long-haired(?) nude male from a supine into a sitting position on the ground. His head is bent back, his arm dangles, and his legs are crossed. He may be dead.

Facing left, a gowned old man with long hair and beard, holding a pitcher with spout and handle, bends over a nude male on the ground. His left foot peeks from beneath his gown, on which is etched "It is Raised / a Spiritual Body," derived from 1 Corinthians 15:44.
Above the group of figures arches the branch of a fruit-bearing tree—perhaps apple—with six or seven round fruits and several leaves. The tree trunk extends upward along the right margin.
Behind the group of figures at lower left may be a mound or hill. The area above the lower design is colored to suggest sky.
There is the suggestion of grass below the female and nude male.
"It is Raised / a Spiritual Body," a verse derived from 1 Corinthians 15:44, is etched vertically on the old man's gown.

lg.l: It is Raised a Spiritual Body

illustration.illusobjdesc: Interlinear decoration is limited to rudimentary flourishes here and there—on both ends of the title, for instance, and at the ends of lines 11 and 16. Light blue wash suggests sky in part of the text area.

component.illusobjdesc: There are a few flourishes—lines that might be described as vine-like—on both ends of the title, for instance, and at the ends of lines 11 and 16.
Light blue washes suggest sky in part of the text.

lg.l: Whate'er is Born of Mortal Birth,
Must be consumed with the Earth
To rise from Generation free;
Then what have I to do with thee?
The Sexes sprung from Shame & Pride
Blowd in the morn; in evening died
But Mercy changd Death into Sleep;
The Sexes rose to work & weep.
Thou Mother of my Mortal part.
With cruelty didst mould my Heart.
And with false self-decieving tears,
Didst bind my Nostrils Eyes & Ears,
Didst close my Tongue in senseless clay
And me to Mortal Life betray:
The Death of Jesus set me free,
Then what have I to do with thee?

l.note: Lines 19-20 are inscribed vertically on the gown of the standing figure on the right.

desc.objtitle:
The School Boy,
Object 53 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are two boys(?) and, at right, a figure of indeterminate sex playing a game of marbles on an area of ground, the bank of a river(?) running along the bottom margin. Behind the right-most figure is a bit of spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children: (bottom to top) one—long-haired and thus perhaps a girl—standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin are a slender tree and a vine intertwined with it with a bird left of the first stanza. There would appear to be a figure standing in this vine, left of the fourth stanza. The background is colored to suggest a cloudy(?) sky with light, possibly of sunrise or sunset, above the horizon.

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game of marbles that he and the other children present are playing.

The short-haired boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. His left leg is bent under him; his right leg is extended to the left. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left who is poised to shoot a marble.

The right-most child in the group below the text, though possibly male, nevertheless appears to be female in the present copy; she has long hair, and she wears either a gown or tights. She is sitting, bending sharply forward with her head and arms down. Though facing left, the girl appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired girl or boy, possibly nude or in tights, stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg. Its left arm fuses with the plant.

A short-haired boy in tights climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing forward, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.

A child in tights, perhaps a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide. The raised heel of his right shoe is distinctly visible.
Facing right, a child (probably male), wearing tights, sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. The figure holds and appears to be reading a book.
The figure sitting at the top of the vines on the right appears to be reading an open book.

A figure wearing a gown stands in the vine left of the fourth stanza. In this copy, the figure merges with the vegetation. She(?) appears to face forward, with her head turned to the right. In this copy, her left(?) arm is bent.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 21.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 8(?). A vine climbs the tree and appears to terminate at about line 25.
The children play a game of marbles on an area of ground, the bank of a river(?) running along the bottom margin.
A river may run along the bottom of the margin, in front of the children playing a game of marbles. This motif is only vaguely suggested by blue coloring in this copy.
The background is colored to suggest a cloudy sky, with an area of light near the top of the illustration that may suggest sunrise or sunset.
Children play a game of marbles. Four marbles are visible on the right side, just below the feet of the right figure.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 2) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. Tendrils from the vines in the right margin—part of the main illustration—are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 2) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The extension on the first title letter dangles down the left margin below the bird.

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
O! what sweet company.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
Under a cruel eye outworn.
The little ones spend the day,
In sighing and dismay.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour.
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Nor sit in learnings bower.
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
But droop his tender wing.
And forget his youthful spring.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And blossoms blown. away.
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
By sorrow and cares dismay.
How shall the summer arise in joy,
Or the summer fruits appear,(troy
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
Or bless the mellowing year.
When the blasts of winter appear.

desc.objtitle:
The Voice of the Ancient Bard,
Object 54 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children—standing in the middle of the group—and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females (the taller possibly male) who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three gowned females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures appear to be gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of grassy and slightly inclined ground. The sky behind and above the figures is delineated by a dark area behind them to the left, a lighter area to the right, and an area of gray and cloudy sky at the top. Yellow tinting behind the harp and above the group of three standing figures hints at a sunrise or sunset. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. The young female, with hair short or pulled back, faces away from the viewer with her visible arm raised vertically to hold the shoulder of her companion. She stands with her left foot forward, her right foot back.

At left stands an embracing couple. Facing left, the short-haired, taller figure might be an older female or a male, gowned(?). He or she looks down at the other figure and holds his or her visible hand on her buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard. The child on the right faces right as he looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females with hair short or pulled back. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm at her side and partly behind her back; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. The central figure has left arm bent at the elbow and extended across her body. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard.
Over the head of the figure at far right arches a palm-like frond.
Green tinting indicates grass on the ground below the figures.

The sky behind and above the figures is delineated by a dark shadowy area behind them to the left and in the corner beside them, a lighter area to the right, and an area of gray and cloudy sky at the top. Yellow tinting behind the harp and above the group of three standing figures hints at a sunrise or sunset.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title (line 3) there is a serpentine vine-like, or leaf-like, form. Left of the first line of the poem (line 4) is a vine that runs down the left margin of the text and dangles over the two embracing figures. Another independent vine sprouts from the end of line 4 and branches into three leaves on three long stems.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title (line 3) there is a serpentine vine-like, or leaf-like, form. Left of the first line of the poem (line 4) is a vine that runs down the left margin of the text and dangles over the two embracing figures. Another independent vine sprouts from the end of line 4 and branches into three leaves on three long stems.

lg.l: Youth of delight come hither.
And see the opening morn,
Image of truth new-born
Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
Dark disputes & artful teazing.
Folly is an endless maze,
Tangled roots perplex her ways,
How many have fallen there!
They stumble all night over bones of the dead:
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led.
